Ottawa, July 29, 1933.

Sir:

In the absence of the Deputy Superintendent General, who is at present in the West, I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, nominating the services of Miss Helen McDougall for the position as teacher of the Eskasoni Indian Day School for the coming academic year and stating the qualifications and experience which she possesses.

In reply I have to say that the Department is pleased to approve of the appointment of Miss McDougall, to begin duties on or about September 5th next, the date on which the school will re-open after the present summer holidays.

The salary allowed Miss McDougall will be at the rate of $75 per teaching month, less 10% during the present fiscal year. Rev. A. R. McDonald, the local Indian Agent, is being informed of the appointment, which, it is noted, is favourably regarded by him. He is being requested to give this teacher every possible assistance in her work at the Eskasoni School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Finlay MacDonald, Esq., M. P.,
Sydney,

Excerpt from annual report March 31, 1908, of A.J. McNeill, M.D., Indian Agent, Eskasoni, N.S.

Education.—There is a school-house situated about the centre of this reserve. A new school-house, however, is badly needed, as the present one is old, having been built about thirty-five years ago. It is small, cold and poorly ventilated, and generally most uncomfortable to both teacher and pupils. School has been conducted here during the past term. At present there are eighteen pupils enrolled. As a rule the attendance is poor, the average daily attendance during the past quarter being only six. This can be accounted for in a measure by the fact that the parents do not take the interest in the school that they should. On the whole, good progress has been made during the past year.
Ottawa, April 8th, 1906.

1. Referring. Please file and direct to schools.

2. Schools. Suppose some action has been taken or will be taken about this school house, and so there can be no harm in publishing this in the annual report.

H. C. Ross
Ottawa, May 1, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Dr. McNeil, Indian Agent at Eskasoni, in his annual report for the year ended March 31, last, under the heading of "Education" calls attention to the necessity for a new school-house, the present one being old and unsuitable. It was built about thirty-five years ago.

They have an enrolment of 18, with an average attendance of about 7. If the Department decides to put up a new school-house, provision would have to be made in the estimates for next year and our Architect would have to prepare plans and specifications, so that an estimate of the cost might be made. The attendance would, no doubt, be improved with a better building and, if a warm mid-day meal could be supplied, it would awaken the interest of the pupils, as the Indians in this locality are poor and their children often kept from school for want of a lunch to take with them.

Sir:-

I beg to inform you that plans and specifications have been prepared for the new Eskasoni school and that tenders for the building are being invited by advertisement in the North Sydney Herald and Sydney Daily Record.

Blueprint plans and specifications in duplicate are being sent you under separate cover for the use of persons wishing to tender for the work.

You are requested to provide a suitable room for the plans where contractor or others wish to tender may estimate on the work, also to hang duplicate copy of plan and specifications to the Post Master at Eskasoni, and make satisfactory arrangements for the display of plan at that point for the use of contractor.

It is assumed that the site of the present school as it is centrally situated, is satisfactory, and that the premises are sufficient in area, are easily drained and have an ample supply of water.

Providing they are not satisfactory will you be good enough to report thereon, with a view of obtaining a more satisfactory site. This is not however to interfere in any way with the taking of tenders for the work at this time.

A copy of the advertisement for the school is enclosed for your information.

Your obedient servant,

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to report that a new school-house being required on the Eskasoni Indian reserve, in the County of Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, and the cost of the new building being covered in the estimates for 1908-10, tenders were called for by the Department of Indian Affairs, receivable up to noon of the 10th April, 1909. The following tender was received:

Chappell Bros. & Co., Limited, of Sydney, N.S.,
for $1975.00

The tender is submitted herewith, as required by Sub-Section 3 of Section 36 of the Public Works Act; and the undersigned would recommend that the same be accepted by Your Excellency in Council.

[Signature]
Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
Indian Agent McNeill reported in March, 1909, that the old school is old, having been built about 35 years ago, that it is small, cold and poorly ventilated & generally most uncomfortable for both teacher & pupils. There are 18 pupils enrolled.

$1000 is included in the estimates for this work. The balance of $975 is available from School Vote for Ontario, Quebec & Maritime Provinces.

Tenders were called for by advt. receivable up to noon of 10th inst. Only one was received up to that time,—that of Messrs. Chappell Bros., for $1975. Another, that of Hugh J. McLellan, of Big Bend Centre, for $1681, was rec'd. on the 13th. It bears Big Bend Centre & Sydney post marks of 8th. It reached Ottawa post office on the 11th (Sunday) and the Dept. on 12th. It appears on referring to the railway time tables that in order to reach Ottawa on the 10th it should have left Sydney on the 7th, or not later than 7.40 A.M., of the 8th. Big Bend Centre is somewhere off the railway line and evidently had to start from Sydney by rail. Chappell Bros' tender was posted at Sydney on the 7th and just reached here on time.

It is presumed that, although Mr. McLellan thought his tender would reach here on time, and his is the lower tender by nearly $300, it should not, in fairness to the other tenderer who took the precaution of submitting his in time, be considered.

Sir,-

I beg to inform you that Messrs. Chappell Bros. & Co., Ltd., of Sydney, C.B., have been awarded the contract for the erection of the Eskasoni Indian School. They have executed a form of contract and bond which have been found satisfactory. I enclose herewith one copy of their contract. When writing the firm on the 10th ultimo the Department pointed out that they had failed to return the blue-print plans and specifications which were sent with other forms for their signature and which form a part of the agreement. As yet these plans and specifications have not reached the Department.

The Department desires that you will see Messrs. Chappell Bros. & Co. without delay and obtain from them the blue-print plans, &c., which you should be careful to see are signed by them. When you receive the same you should hand over to them the copy of contract herewith enclosed. It is desired that you will lose no time in attending to this matter, as the Department is anxious that the work on the building should be begun and pushed forward to completion without delay.

I may add that the Department has arranged with Mr. Rory H. McKinnon, of Castle Bay, Highlands, to inspect the building while it is in course of construction.

General Conditions

The contractors are to give their personal supervision to the work, to furnish all necessary materials, labour, apparatus, scaffolding and utensils needful for performing the work in the best and most satisfactory manner according to the drawings and these particulars prepared for the same and are intended to include everything necessary and requisite for the full and entire completion of the building, without exception, notwithstanding that every item necessarily involved in the works is not particularly mentioned, and work shown and not specified and vice versa, to be done as if both shown and specified.

All the material to be the best of the sorts and qualities specified and all to be sound and firm.

At completion the work to be given up in a complete and undamaged state without exception.

All the work to be finished in a plain and substantial way as specified and directed and to be to the entire satisfaction of an officer of the Department of Indian Affairs appointed for this purpose.
Masonry

Excavation: Excavate to the depth form and size as shown on foundation plan for foundation walls and piers. Excavation to be one foot larger than walls to allow for footing and pointing up of stone work.

The excavated earth will be stacked on the lot and levelled at completion to grade directed and required.

Walls: The stone foundation walls will have a footing course of large flat stones 6" thick and extending, at least 6" on each side of walls above.

Carry up the walls marked stone of the dimensions shown on drawings of good quality local stones laid on their natural bed and well packed and hearted and flushed up each course with good mortar; and having at least, three stones extending entirely through walls as bond stones to each yard of face work.
Pointing: The outside of stone wall from grade line up will be neatly pointed up at completion with good cement mortar showing natural outline of stones.

The walls below grade line to footing course to be well and carefully flushed up.

Lime Mortar: The mortar to be of the best quality, composed of fresh burned grey lime, clean sharp sand and water, mixed in proportion of three of sand to one of lime and for cement mortar two parts of cement in addition.

Brick work: Build chimneys of good quality hard burned brick, and carried through roof and finished as shown on drawing. The chimney to be well flushed up full each course and parged on inside of flue. The portions showing above roof to be laid in cement mortar.

Piers: Build up as required brick or stone piers of the height and dimensions shown on plan and to bed level in good mortar, beams and all necessary plates on pier, walls, etc., to carry joisting.
Beam-filling:-

Beam-fill from stone work to eighteen inches above floor line with brick or stone or mortar grout firmly rammed solid to steady frame work.

Beam fill also from plate to top of rafters with grout to exclude air at roof, all to be done in a good and workmanlike and satisfactory manner.
Carpentering and Joining

Sills:-
The sills for frame will be of 2" x 6" in long lengths and well spike-nailed together with 4" nails.

The sills will be evenly and firmly bedded level on stone foundation as shown and strongly and firmly secured together at corners.

Beams:-
The beams will be of three pieces of 2" x 8" strongly nailed and bedded level on piers as shown.

Joists:-
The joists for ground floor will be of 2" x 12", ceiling joists 2" x 8" set at 16" centres, bridged twice in length with 2" x 2" herring-boned bridging well nailed at each end with 2½" wire nails. The joisting will be firmly nailed to sills or plates at each end with 4" spike-nails.

Frame work:-
Build frame work of 2" x 4" scantling set at 16" centres, and having plates of 2" x 4" doubled in long lengths and well and firmly spiked-nailed together and at all angles. The feet of studding to rest on sills and to be strongly spike-nailed to sills or plates and to sides of joists with 4" nails.
Angle bracing:-
Angle brace of 2" x 4" to be cut running from outside wall to centre at ceiling on every wall strongly nailed to studding.

Roof:-
The rafters will be of 2" x 6" set at 16" centres, framed at heel and well and strongly spike-nailed to plates and together with 4" spike-nails.

Collar ties:-
Provide and fix collar ties of 2" x 6" nailed to all rafters with hangers of 2" x 6" to ceiling joists as shown, strongly spike-nailed at each end.

Rough boarding:-
Cover all the outside frame and roof with good quality of narrow 7/8" spruce, pine, hemlock or fir shiplap boarding well nailed, close jointed with at least two 3" nails to each board, at each crossing of studding or rafter, the interior walls will be sheeted up with good quality of similar material on building paper before plastering.

Strapping:-
The interior of all exterior walls will be strapped with 7/8" spruce or pine strapping, strongly nailed to boarding at 16" centres for plastering.
Siding:

The exterior walls will be covered with good building paper on shiplap and finished with good quality of narrow dry pine weather board siding. The siding will be neatly fitted and well and strongly nailed to boarding with 2½" finishing nails.

Provide and fix at all angles 7/8" x 4" corner strip to which siding will finish and to be strongly nailed to frame work as required.

Water table:

Provide and fix in position shown, water table formed of 2" x 6" bevelled as required, spike-nailed to frame work.

Shingles:

The roof to be covered with best quality of Canadian cedar shingles laid at 4½" to weather on ¼" hair mortar, double thicknesses of asbestos or tarred roofing felt and nailed with best quality of 1¼" steel shingle nails of Canadian manufacture, and to have, at least two nails to each 4" shingle.

Flooring:

Cover the ground floor joists with good quality of narrow rough spruce, hemlock, pine, fir or cedar, boarding laid diagonally and with close joints and well nailed to joisting with 3" nails. Cover this sub-floor with two thicknesses of oiled building or tarred roofing paper, then lay on ground floor joists good quality of narrow tongued and grooved flooring, blind-nailed with 3" finishing
Trim:

All doors and windows to be trimmed with a neat 5" architraves, all to be hand-smoothed and put on in a good and workmanlike manner.

Wainscoting:

Sheet up walls of class-room, cloak-room and porch to a height of 4 ft. 6" with narrow V jointed pine sheeting hand-smoothed and strongly blind-nailed to walls. Provide and fix thereon suitable cap for the same.

Window frames:

Provide and fix 7/8" pine box window frames of size shown, having all necessary hanging stiles, blind stiles, outside and inside linings, stops, parting strips, sills, sub-sills, back band, etc., complete, and to have 1½" sash double hung with best quality cast iron pulleys and silver lake sash cord and 1½" storm sash to all windows all to have suitable lifts and fasts put on complete.

Door and frames:

Provide and fix suitable front porch and rear, outside door frames as shown, formed of 2" pine, rebated for 1½" door, having all necessary lining, oak sill, etc. with back band for storm doors.
Exterior doors:

All exterior doors will be of good quality of dry 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" white pine, panelled, mortised and tenoned, doors strongly framed and glued and fitted together. Panels to be balustrade moulded and to be neatly fitted.

All to be hung with good quality of 4" loose pin steel butts (three to exterior doors) and locked with a good quality of brass faced and bolted mortise door locks with necessary roses, plates, etc., complete as required.

Inside frames:

Provide and fix 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" pine jambs for doorways, openings shown entering cloak-rooms, to be firmly fixed plumb and straight to walls and partitions. (No doors are required for these openings).

Outside steps:

The outside steps to be built as shown, formed of 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" treads, \(7/8\) risers, 2" strings, all to be well and firmly put together and nailed, and to have strong carriage pieces supporting strings.

Porches:

The porches will be built as shown and in every way constructed as specified for other portions of the building.
Belfry:

Provide and build a small neat belfry of 6" x 6" posts, and 2" x 6" bracing and neat shingled top as shown on drawing and for which a detailed drawing will be supplied.

Blackboards:

The contractor to put in ribboned pieces of 1" stuff extending full length of blackboard at top and bottom of same and upright pieces firmly nailed to them between studs, for blackboard, making centre for studs 8" instead of 16" as for other portions of plastered werk.
Lathing and Plastering

Lath all walls, partitions, ceilings, etc., not otherwise specified with good quality of narrow moderately dry, pine laths, free from sap, shakes, bark or knots. Laths to be strongly nailed to supports etc., 3/8" apart, with 1 3-8" steel lath nails and joints broken every 18" in height.

Brown coat:

Give all portions lathed one good coat of brown hair mortar, composed of fresh burned gray lime, clean sharp sand and water with sufficient cow or goat hair to make good and lasting work. The brown coat to be put on with sufficient pressure to ensure good key. All angles to be made plumb and straight and true; and all surfaces level.

The brown coat to be at least half an inch thick.

Finishing coat:

When the brown coat is dry all to have a good coat of hard white plaster of Paris finish, well gauged and trowelled to a hard and even surface, free from all blemish or defect, and at completion the contractor to make good breaks and damage whether caused by his own work or by reason of completion of other trades.

Cleaning:

The plasterer must clean all lime from walls, floor, trim and all wood work before handing work over to painters.
Blackboards:

The portions of plastered walls used for blackboard to have 1/3 Portland cement used with the brown mortar, making a hard and firm surface for finishing coat.

Finishing Coats:

The finishing coats to be composed of white lime putty coloured with black mortar color and Portland cement in equal proportions and floated smooth.
Painting and glazing

Paint all the exposed wood and iron work (interior and exterior) usually painted three good coats of lead and oil, tinted as directed by officer in charge.

The lead to be used will be best Canadian white lead, pure boiled linseed oil and pure turpentine as dryer.

All work to be carefully knotted with best shellac before priming. When priming coat is dry the work to be carefully stepped with best white lead putty and sandpapered. All to be finished with a flowing coat of lead and oil, tinted as directed.

All floors throughout the building will be finished three coats of oil. First coat to be put on as soon as floors are laid and cleaned off.

Glazing:

The whole of the windows throughout the building to be glazed with double diamond English sheet glass of Pilkington manufacture, all to be free from winds, bands, air bubbles, etc. All glass to be sprigged, bedded, and back and front puttied and left clean at completion.
Tin and galvanized iron work

Provide and fix necessary volleys and cloak flashings over all window and door frames and belfrey to prevent water getting behind frames, etc. The flashings to be of, at least, 6" in width and to be fixed in position before siding and shingles are put on. Chimneys will be step flashed and cloak flashed also form and cover saddle at rear as shown.

Girt:

Provide and fix 12" girt saves trough to all cornices as required with same diameter conductor pipe. All to have necessary bends, elbows, rods, hooks and fasteners, etc. Conductor pipe will be kept 3" from face of walls.

All galvanized iron to be Lysaght Queen's Head Brand, twenty-eight gauge (28) galvanized iron.

Dear Sir,

Enclose return for quarter ended Sept. 30th.

When I came here to open the school on the 23rd of last August, I found the schoolroom filled up with material which Messrs Chapell Bros were using in building the new schoolhouse. They begged for the use of the room for another two weeks, and they told me that the Chief had given his consent to this. I told them that I was going to write to the Agent about the matter, and I did so after my returning home. I notified the Agent that I went to Eskasoni to open the school, but was prevented from doing so because the schoolroom was used as a storehouse and cooking-room by the contractors, and I notified him further that I would demand salary for every day I should be idle because on account of being prevented from getting into the schoolroom. I lost ten teaching days, and I now respectfully ask the Department to pay me for the same. I had the consent of the Department to open the school on the day I came here to open it.
It is time now that steps be taken to move into the new school house, but before this can be done, the service of some handy person must be secured to move in the furniture, stove, etc., and put them properly into their places. Three or four links of stove pipe must be bought, and when the winter sets in the storm windows shall have to be put up. I would recommend that R. H. McKinnon of Castle Bay be appointed to attend to these matters.

I am sorry to see that no steps are taken to furnish a well. We have no drinking water here except what we get out of an open well near the house of an Indian, and sometimes the notion will strike him to forbid us taking any out it, as he did several times last year when I had to take a flask of water with me every day for six months. His well is the only good water in this vicinity, but it is not safe for us to be drinking it because of the impurities liable to get into it. If the Department would fix up this well and put a pump into it, it would not cost much.
A new school house is a gem, but its surroundings are far from being attractive. There is no play ground except the public highway, and the forest primed extends to within a few feet from the walls of the school. If this condition be allowed to exist for much time, the building may go up in smoke.

Again, a janitor should be appointed to kindle the fire, sweep and wash the floor. Mrs. Christopher Morris who lives alongside the school would be a good person to look after this work; but the supplying of the fuel should be left with Joseph Denny the man who has had the job for years back.

Yours respectfully,

A.J. McKenzie

The Director, Surveys and Engineering Branch.

A discussion took place yesterday in Dr. Cassell's office, with the Architect of your branch, Dr. Cassell and officials of this branch in regard to the question of the acceptance of any of the tenders for the buildings on the Eskimo Reserve, N.S., and while it is realized that the tenders received are not in accordance with any estimates of costs prepared by your staff, it is thought that we should definitely decide to proceed with the program.

The Superintendent of Welfare and Training at the meeting stated that in his opinion the construction of these buildings was so urgent that they should be proceeded with regardless of cost, and that an attempt should be made to ascertain whether the contractors could effect any reduction in their prices by deferring the commencement of the program until weather conditions were better and not later than May 1st. The Deputy Minister agreed with this suggestion.

I may say that there are over 100 pupils who should be attending school on the Eskimo Reserve. There is accommodation in the present school for 25 pupils only. Our program of centralization is, therefore, at a standstill until school accommodation can be provided, and the present school lacks not only sufficient accommodation but is a very poor building. We are forced, therefore, to keep in operation three day schools at various other locations which could be closed if we had a school on the Eskimo Reserve.

Will you kindly get in touch with the contractors who tendered on the three buildings at the earliest possible date and advise them that we intend to have the buildings constructed but that it is thought advisable to defer the program until May 1st, 1945 approximately, when weather conditions will be more favourable, and ask them whether there would be any reduction in their tenders for construction of the buildings to commence not later than May 1st?

As the money voted for the construction of these buildings is not likely to be used during the present fiscal year, it is desired to know whether it would be practical and feasible to proceed at once with the water supply systems and power plants for both Eskimo and Sinibosadie Reserves, or with the purchase of materials if the actual work of installation cannot be carried out.

Re: Buildings for Agency Development,
Eskasoni Indian Agency, Nova Scotia.

With further reference to suggestions advanced by Father Ross in connection with the above, and our memorandum of January 25, 1945, additional comment, from an architectural aspect, on the various points raised is supplied for your use as requested, in the order they appear in Lists "A" and "B".

List A Day School and Principal's Residence.

Item 1. The service road necessary to service the site must be built on a fairly steep hill. It has been planned to follow contours which will allow reasonable gradients with a minimum amount of fill and excavation. The road is to be provided by the Indian Affairs branch and will not be included in the contract. It can best serve the site in the position shown on the block plan.

2. Neither flushing type or chemical toilets have been considered for the school. Outside toilets with receptacles removable for frequent emptying and cleaning, were considered satisfactory, and have been provided for in the specifications. Under efficient operation a disinfectant would be used. The additional cost for acceptable chemical toilets would be in excess of $500, and for flush-type toilets with an additional septic tank approximately $1000.

3. Hot air heating was considered the most satisfactory installation for the school and principal's residence, where plumbers and steamfitters would not be readily available. It would be the less expensive installation and eliminates the possibility of mechanical trouble. Hot air is still an acceptable type of heating for high standard buildings. While hot water permits better distribution of heat, it does not provide additional moisture to the heated rooms, unless air conditioning humidifiers are installed. The change from hot air to hot water installation would add about $1200 to the cost of the School, and approximately $500 to the cost of the Principal's Residence.

4. A fireplace for the Principal's Residence would add approximately $500 to the cost.

5. No additional accommodation can be provided in the Principal's Residence unless it is re-designed. The additional cost would depend on the changes involved, but would not be less than $1000.

List B Teachers' Residence

Item 1. This item is confused in its wording. The intended
request is for the installation of hot water heating in place of hot air. Hot air heating was approved for the building as for all others. To install the hot water would cost an approximate additional amount of $300.

Item 2 to 9. These are items which demand re-study of allotted space if they are considered necessary. Changed positions of doors and windows, additions of small rooms, cupboards, toilet fixtures, etc., with consequent adjustments to heating ducts, cold air returns, water piping, etc., will, of course, increase the size of the building and services. Their effect on the cost cannot be definitely estimated without revised drawings, but at least a $1400 increase would be involved. In Items 3 and 9, references to "Chapel" and "Oratory" concern the same space.

10. We understand future buildings on the site will include a recreational building, but no provision is being made for such accommodation at this time.

The rough estimates embodied herein total an additional cost for the project of $3200, or $1800 more than the figure given in our memorandum of January 25 last. The difference is the amount involved if hot water heating were installed in the School, to which possibility our Architect had given no consideration.

The effect that incorporation of these items would have on working drawings and specifications to be used in obtaining tenders for the work next spring was described in our memorandum of January 25, but it is not proposed to initiate any changes to drawings or specifications unless we are instructed to do so.

(Sgd.) T.S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Sirs:-

No doubt you have received my telegram of the 16th, informing you of the Sisters' unwillingness to occupy their residence unless the recommendations they made last Fall are carried out.

I can easily understand their action. They are few in number, and generous offers are being made to them from other localities. To my mind their recommendations are reasonable, and should be carried out. These Sisters are persons of experience who know the value of what they want, and every effort should be made to look after their needs. It is impossible to estimate, in terms of dollars and cents, the good work the Sisters will accomplish in Eskasoni.

I have been looking over the plans for the new buildings. I made three recommendations last Fall about the plan of the Principal's residence. I see that these recommendations were not accepted.

The recommendations are:-

1. That hot water be used in heating the house instead of hot air. There are several reasons why this change should be made.

2. There are only three bedrooms; one for the priest, one for the housekeeper and one for the girl or boy servant. On some occasions it will be necessary for the Bishop of the Diocese to visit here, and on other occasions it will be necessary to have another clergyman to help me, such, for instance, as during the Forty Hours' Devotion, Confirmations, Missions, etc., and there should be at least one other bedroom, as otherwise either the help or the visiting assistant or assistants would have no place to sleep. In any case it is very undesirable to have the help sleeping on the same floor, and it is particularly objectionable in the case of a small house such as this. All that is necessary is to raise the roof three or four feet higher and finish a couple of rooms on the top floor for the help.

3. It is desirable to have a modest fireplace in the living room. Apart from giving a cheerful atmosphere to the room, it will take the place of the fire in the furnace in the early Fall and late Spring. To economize in this way will justify the expense of a fireplace.

I sincerely trust that you will give effect to these recommendations. If you wish to get the Sisters there, it is extremely important that you co-operate with them.

As for my own quarters, I think my suggestions are very modest and it does seem to me that you will have some difficulty in getting clergymen to stay there unless these recommendations are carried out.

Sincerely yours,

A. A. Ross.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Eskasoni Indian Day School.

With reference to the above, Reverend Father Ross, Principal of the School, was sent to Ottawa last week by His Lordship the Bishop of Antigonish, with a long list of changes that it was felt should be made in the Principal's residence and in the Sisters' residence.

Bishop Morrison has been very co-operative with the Department in our program at Eskasoni, and I felt that the changes requested should be very carefully considered.

In company with Mr. Phelan, I carefully considered the representations made by Father Ross, and it was pointed out to him that if we made all the changes suggested it would involve an extra expenditure of approximately $6,000.00, and besides, would necessitate radical changes in the plans and specifications, which would necessarily delay the erection of the buildings. As a result of our discussion, it was finally agreed with Father Ross that he would be satisfied if the method of heating was changed from hot air to hot water and some provision was made for an extra bedroom in the Principal's residence.

Following this interview, I arranged to have Father Ross and Mr. Phelan interview Mr. Jackson and discuss the matter with him. Later, Father Ross and Mr. Phelan spent some time with our Architect, Mr. Buck. For your information, I enclose a copy of a memorandum which I am forwarding today to the Surveys & Engineering Branch.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of June 5th., No. 50-1-1, concerning receipt from C.N.R. for transportation and Berths, I am enclosing herewith the receipt.

I am very disappointed at not having received a reply to our telephone conversation of Monday June 11th., re erection this year of the Principal's residence at Eskasoni. As the Archbishop is very anxious to get this information immediately, I sent you a telegram on Friday the 15th. To date, no reply has been received. It is difficult to understand this delay in view of the fact that you told me on the telephone that you would let me know as soon as you would check about the matter that afternoon with Mr. Hoey.

The Archbishop has permitted my being being appointed Principal, and he appointed me Parish Priest, on the understanding that suitable living quarters would be erected by the Department this year. If you are not going to erect a house, it will not be built at the expense of the diocese, and the Indians cannot afford this expense. Then, you will likely have to dispense with my services here, for I will not under any condition spend another winter in the house I was in last year. To this, I may add that, in years to come, you will find it next to impossible to obtain the services of another priest for Eskasoni from the Bishop of Antigonish.

Yours sincerely,

A. A. Ross,
Principal.

Ottawa, June 22, 1945.

Dear Father Ross:

I have your letter of the 19th instant and also received your telegram of the 15th instant, in connection with your telephone conversation of June 11.

Please understand that the decision regarding the erection of the buildings is handled by the highest officials in the Department. The quotation received for the Principal's residence was in the vicinity of $13,000.00, which, in view of our Architect's estimate of approximately $9,000.00, was considered altogether too high. Consequently, the decision was made not to proceed with the erection of the Principal's residence this year.

It is intended to proceed with the erection of the Agency residence and the warehouse and agent's office, owing to the fact that the tenders obtained for these were reasonably close to our Architect's estimate. Mr. Armstrong, of the Welfare Division, is proceeding to Eskasoni at the end of this week and will have an opportunity of meeting you. He has discussed the situation regarding your residence with both Mr. Hoey and myself and will have one or two proposals to make.

In addition, arrangements have been completed this afternoon to have our Surveys and Engineering Branch approach the firm who were successful in obtaining the erection of the two agency buildings, with a view to

PRESENT EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES — At present the educational facilities consist of one old school building in a poor condition at the east end of the reserve. Thirty-eight children were in attendance—crowded. The children appeared to be in a healthy condition, well dressed, and well fed. Miss Margaret Maclean is the teacher in charge. She is fully qualified but not experienced.

At the west end of the reserve a one-roomed welfare house was made available. It is not suitable. However, it is absolutely necessary as a number of children have lost three years and had not been to schools since moved to Shubenacadie until this term. The location of proposed day school on Eskasoni reserve.

I have your letter of November 22nd re the above for acknowledgement.

I have looked over the Christmas plot referred to and find that it too has quite an elevation which would require a great amount of levelling and grade work before a playground could be made of it. I feel that the work required would be justified only as a last resort. In that location it would have the advantage of being away from the office and residences, allowing more room for other buildings like a detachment house, teacher's residence, medical residence or nursing station which will, I imagine, have to be reasonably close to the water supply and sewerage facilities. Should the school be located there, there would be ample room for the children to romp around and the grounds could be well supplied with swings, tilts, etc lacking however ball diamond facilities.

With the exception of this plot no other locale would be suitable. I thought first of the level field across the highway but on investigation I found that occasionally, in spring floods, the water covers enough of this field to make it unsatisfactory.

If the site we selected was not considered too far a walk for the children at the extreme ends of the reserve what would be wrong with erecting a school there with six classrooms which, I believe, would accommodate all the children we will ever have here. I understand that there will be classrooms in the basement for domestic science and manual training instruction which should give ample room space for almost any eventuality.

While on the subject of school I would ask that the plans be amended to include wiring for electricity. The basement rooms would be an ideal meeting place for homemakers club meetings etc and besides there are many days when students need the assistance of artificial lighting at their desks.

I would also ask for the inclusion of an indoor toilet and running water for the teachers, who, I understand, will be members of a religious order. This could be quite easily done by installing a septic tank, digging a small well of domestic size, and using a small electric pressure tank and pump. These outfits are common around here and are quite economical to install and maintain. This would be all the more necessary if the school is located some distance from the immediate vicinity of their residence.

F. B. McKinnon,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, January 17, 1946.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
SURVEYS and ENGINEERING BRANCH

Re: New Eskasoni Indian Day School
and Teacher's Residence.

Mr. F. B. McKinnon, Indian Agent for Eskasoni,
Mr. J. E. Morris and Mr. Phelan interviewed Mr. Buck
this morning, with reference to the following changes
which we would like to have made, if possible, in the
plans of the above building:

1. The height of the basement should be increased
and the posts removed. This would permit our
using the basement as a community centre until
such time as we are in a position to erect a
building for the latter purpose only. This would
also involve the provision of another exit, so
that it will be easy to leave the building in
case of any trouble.

2. The school should be wired for electricity.

3. If at all possible, a toilet should be provided
in the school for the use of the staff members.

4. Hot water heating should be supplied instead of
hot air heating in the teacher's residence. The
coal used in Nova Scotia is soft and with hot air
heating the interior of the building would have
to be redecorated much oftner than if hot water
is used.

It is extremely important that both the school
and the teacher's residence should be ready for occupancy
by September 1, 1946, if at all possible. The lack of adequate educational facilities is delaying the completion of our program at Eskasoni; consequently it would be appreciated if arrangements could be made to have the construction of the new building commenced as soon as weather conditions permit.

Director.

Re: Construction of Buildings at Eskasoni Indian Agency

As referred to in my memorandum to you of the 15th ultimo, the Engineering and Construction Service contacted Mr. M.R. Chappell, Contractor, Sydney, Nova Scotia, in regard to erecting the 4-roomed Day School and Teachers' Residence on a cost plus fixed fee basis. This arrangement would relieve the contractor of any possibility of loss that might result from present shortages in building supplies and labour, and there was a possibility that the work could be done at a lower price than his lump sum tender of $53,000.

Attached herewith is a copy of a memorandum from Mr. Mills, dated June 22nd, with which is forwarded a copy of Mr. Chappell's offer dated June 20th. You will note that his estimated costs are about the same in either case. In the case of the work being done by a lump sum contract, the total cost to the Department would be $53,000. Any extra work that would be found necessary might not exceed $1,000.

Under a cost plus fixed fee contract we would pay the contractor the actual cost of the work plus a fixed fee of $3,500. If there are no great delays due to lack of labour and building materials, I think that the buildings could be built for less than $50,000, exclusive of the fixed fee. However, under present building conditions,
and in view of the fact that the contractor could not lose money, we could pay more than the contractor's tender of $53,000.

I have discussed to some extent with our officers, the possibilities of doing the work by day labour, but this was regarded as impracticable due to the following disadvantages:

(a) Difficulty in obtaining a first-class building Superintendent, as such men can get employment in any city.

(b) Difficulty in getting carpenters and assistants at other than very high wages, due to the demand for this class of labour in the Halifax area.

(c) Difficulty of obtaining equipment to make foundation excavations in isolated areas.

(d) Necessity of establishing a camp and headquarters for the men on the project.

(e) Certain delays in obtaining building materials which would run the project into the next fiscal year.

Under all the circumstances it is the opinion that if these buildings must be erected in 1946-47, the Chappell lump sum tender of $53,000 will have to be accepted.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 23 July 1946.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 18th July, 1946, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That under Vote 182 of the 1946-47 estimates of the Department of Mines and Resources, funds have been provided to erect two new buildings at the Eskasoni Indian Agency in the province of Nova Scotia, namely:

(a) four-room Indian Day School with outside toilets.
(b) School Teachers' Residence.

That lump sum tenders were invited on the basis of drawings and specifications prepared by the Department, through public advertisement in Nova Scotia newspapers;

That the only tender received was submitted by M.R. Chappell of Sydney, Nova Scotia, whose tender for the two buildings was $53,000.00, which with provision for contingencies and supervision would involve a total expenditure of approximately $58,300.00;

That while the tender was submitted by a contractor who had previously executed satisfactory construction work for the Department, and who is considered to be in a more favourable position to furnish materials, equipment and labour than other contractors in the province who did not tender, the tender submitted was higher than the Department's estimate, and it was felt that the tender might have anticipated rising costs for materials, labour and equipment to a higher degree than might occur;

That it was, therefore, decided to request from Mr. Chappell, a revised tender based on payment to the contractor of the actual cost of construction plus a fixed fee, which would permit the department to exercise control over the contractor's quantities and purchasing, reducing vital expenditures to the minimum;

That Mr. Chappell submitted a revised tender on that basis in which he estimated the cost as follows:

Estimated construction costs for the Indian Day School and Teachers' Residence........................................$50,147.00
Plus a fixed fee of approximately 1%..................................................3,500.00

Total..............$53,647.00

The Honourable
the Minister of Mines and Resources
With provision for contingencies and supervision, a contract awarded on this basis would involve an estimated total expenditure of approximately $59,000.00; and

That while the revised estimate shows a slight increase over the lump sum tender, the contractor's bills of quantities, invoices and pay rolls are subject to approval by the Department, by which means the actual cost may be lower than the contractor's estimated cost.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to enter into a cost plus fixed fee contract with Mr. Chappell of Sydney, N.S., for the erection of the said four-room Indian Bay School and the said Peabody Residence at the Nakasen Indian Agency in the Province of Nova Scotia, in accordance with drawings and specifications prepared by the Department of Mines and Resources at an estimated cost of Fifty-three Thousand Six Hundred and Forty-seven Dollars ($53,647.00), including the Contractor's fixed fee of Three Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($3,500) and entailing with provisions for contingencies and supervision an estimated total expenditure of Fifty-nine Thousand Dollars ($59,000), the said expenditure to be met from the appropriate Votes of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

School Bus Requirements

There are two schools for which we will require busses to provide transportation for Indian children for September 1, 1947. These two schools are:

1. Eskasoni Day School
2. Mount Elgin Day School.

1. Eskasoni Day School

This is a four-room school now being completed on the Eskasoni Reserve, Cape Breton, N.S. The Indians from the scattered reserves throughout this province are being concentrated on this big reservation where adequate medical care, educational facilities and other social services can be made available.

In line with consolidated school policies of provincial departments of education, a four-room school was erected rather than having four small one-room school houses scattered over the reserve. In this way we will also be able to offer vocational training for both boys and girls—a thing that is impossible in a one-room school.

A 30 passenger bus will be required to transport these children living at a distance greater than 3 miles from the
school. It is estimated there will be some forty odd children so located and that two trips will be necessary.

2. Mt. Elgin Day School

Here we converted an old residential school into a day school. Actually this is a high school, drawing the older pupils from the smaller schools on the reserve. In November, 1946, a Ford 1½ ton ex-Army Ambulance was purchased as a school bus. This bus has been over-crowded all winter and we have been highly gratified at the pupils' response to the higher education that we are offering.

Actually it has proven very much cheaper to run this as a day school rather than a residential school. However, there will be some 65 pupils in attendance at this school in September and further transportation will have to be provided. At the present time the former ambulance is making 2 trips each morning and each afternoon. The school is being conducted from 8:30 until 5:00 in order to accommodate those children who arrive early and those who arrive later.

This reserve is a very large one and the school is in the centre. With the larger number of students who will pass their entrance in June it will be absolutely essential to provide another bus for them. The former ambulance can then do the loop to the east of the school and the new bus can do the loop to the west of the school.

In both instances, War Assets Corporation have been written concerning the provision of these busses and they have reported no results in their endeavours to locate suitable vehicles. These letters are attached.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

School Buses for Caradoc and Eskasoni Indian Day Schools.

Reference your 73169-15-11 73170-15-11 of October 28th.

The answers to the questions raised by the Government Motor Vehicle Committee, concerning the purchase of these two buses are as follows:

(1) Q. How many buses does the Department expect to purchase for the purpose of transporting Indian children to and from school?

A. This will depend upon the recommendations of the Parliamentary Committee into the Indian Act. At the present time indications are that they will favour the operation of day schools over residential schools. If this is the case then it will become the gradual policy of the Department to reduce the number of residential schools and to operate day schools in their places. These consolidated day schools will require buses to carry the children daily to school.

(2) Q. Where will they be located?

A. At the present time there are only four centres at which we feel these will be required. These are, Caradoc, Ontario, Eskasoni, Nova Scotia, Wikwemikong, Ontario and Six Nations, Ontario. At the first two places buses are definitely required at the present time. It is not anticipated that our building plans will have proceeded
far enough at the other two Reserves to necessitate the purchase of buses until next year.

(3) Q. Approximately how many children will be carried at each centre?

A. At Caradoc there are fifty children and at Eskasoni there are seventy children. At Six Nations and at Wikwemikong, the progress made in our building plans will decide the number who will have to be transported.

(4) Q. How many round trips per day per vehicle?

A. At Caradoc there will be two round trips per day as long as the old bus continues to function. In bad weather when we are unable to use the old bus, the new bus will have to do four round trips per day (See attached map).

At Eskasoni there will be two round trips per day.

(5) Q. What is the minimum and maximum distances from homes to schools at each centre?

A. Our policy in this regard is to follow the regulations usually followed by Provincial Departments of Education. This is to the effect that children under ten years of age can be expected to walk up to two miles to school and that children over ten years of age can be expected to walk up to three miles.

The maps attached hereto will show clearly the long distances involved in these two places.

(6) Q. How do the children get to school presently at each centre?

A. At Caradoc the residential school was closed on the understanding that a day school would be opened and that transportation for these children would be provided as prescribed in the Indian Act. We are unable to get tenders for the provision of a new bus, therefore, we obtained a former army ambulance. We are using this to do one circuit on the Caradoc Reserve and are using an open farm truck on the smaller circuit.
It is our intention to use the new bus on the larger circuit and to use the ambulance bus on the smaller circuit. At the present time we are running grave risks and are endangering the health and safety of these children by transporting them in an open farm truck.

The school block at the former residential school is one hundred years old and has been condemned but we have a new four room school now being rushed to completion. The school population on this Reserve has grown to such an extent that at the present time we are conducting classes in a church basement and in an agricultural hall as well as in the other school buildings previously provided. We can, undoubtedly, fill this new bus to capacity and within a short time have many standees. This new school will also operate as a consolidated high school.

At Eskasoni, the Indian Affairs Branch has been carrying out a large consolidation scheme by moving Indians from isolated Reserves of Nova Scotia to a centralized Reserve ideally located at Eskasoni. We have just completed a four room day school and have hired a staff of fully qualified teachers. The enrolment at this school is, at the present time one hundred and twenty and of these some sixty require transportation, (See attached map). We are using our farm truck to transport daily these sixty children back and forth to the school. This truck is an open panel model and we have stationed our Indian policemen on it daily to protect those carried. Here again, we are seriously endangering the health and safety of these children, until we provide them with a closed in vehicle as required by the school laws of every one of the nine provinces.

(7) Q. Under what authority is transportation by Government vehicles provided?

A. Section 9 (3) of the Indian Act reads as follows:
"The Superintendent General (Minister) may provide for the transporting of Indian children to and from a boarding or industrial school to which they are assigned.

Could we please have returned the Caradoc map attached hereto, as this is an official document required by the Indian Agent concerned.

Memorandum

SUPERINTENDENT OF INDIAN EDUCATION

Re: Eskasoni Indian Day School

The enrolment at this school has increased more rapidly than was expected. There is an actual enrolment of 154 pupils. This would occupy 40 seats in each room. An increase of 25 pupils is expected next year while only 11 are expected to leave. The Department will have to plan on some construction in order to alleviate the situation. Some attention will have to be devoted to the older boys.

Besides crowding there arises the question of proper sanitation. Should the housing expansion continue there will be another influx of families which will make the situation quite critical. A definite statement of policy would be in order so that the Educational Division may plan for future education.

Transportation has been provided although very few pupils exceed the three mile limit. The reserve in itself in only approximately four and a half miles across. 104 pupils take advantage of this transportation. This requires two trips morning and night. A number of those that are being transported are close enough to the school to walk, but as the bus is not sufficient to accommodate all in one trip this leaves sufficient space to accommodate those that could walk.

The pupils are transported at the noon hour in order that they may take advantage of having their lunch at home. This seems to be justified by the fact that no space for lunch in the school is available. To accommodate this number it would be necessary to use three of the classrooms and require three supervisors. The inconvenience that this would cause would be very difficult on the teachers. This extra transportation means approximately 15 miles a day and would entail an expenditure of less than $20.00 a month. The advantages for the teachers and the advantages for the pupils justify this further expenditure.

The basement of the school has been divided on the Domestic Science side into two apartments, and on the Manual Training side into three. In the Domestic Science room a stage has been built which occupies a depth of 15 feet and is the whole width of the room. I do not think that the advantages of this division justifies the curtailment of the space that could be used for Domestic Science. I therefore recommend that this partition be removed and that a good Domestic Science unit be provided. The provision of a Domestic Science unit will necessitate the construction of a storage space for the kitchen work. The unit should also have storage space for sewing material.

There are 59 girls following the Domestic Science course. At the time of my inspection there was a display of sewing which was being appraised by the Department of Education of N.S. The ladies who were carrying on this work expressed their satisfaction at the splendid work that was displayed.
The Domestic Science teacher is leaving us at the end of June, but before leaving she has agreed to submit a requisition and also suggestions for the improvement of this Department.

The Manual Training shop section of the school is divided into a handicraft room, a manual training department, and a music room. Very little manual training is being taught. Some leather work is being carried on in the handicrafts but in a very limited quantity and of a rather poor quality. The arts taught in this apartment is worth while.

The work for the boys need to be thoroughly re-organized. This brings to the fore the question of a manual training instructor. There are but 7 boys in the senior room which comprises grades 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. This number would not justify the employment of a manual training instructor. If a part-time man could be obtained it would answer the needs for some time. I understand the agency is endeavouring to obtain an employee to take charge of the woodwork shop that is being organized for adults. Should they succeed in obtaining the right type, the Educational Division might arrange to use the services of this man for part-time instruction in the school.

The teachers show a great deal of enthusiasm in their work which is a very good indication.

The school has adopted the school hours as suggested in an official letter of some time ago and this seems to work satisfactorily. They have not, however, discontinued transportation at the noon hour as they were waiting for this official visit. I let them understand that they will be notified of any changes officially from this office. There is no point in making any change this year but I suggest that early instructions be sent for next year's operation.

Respectfully submitted,

A. J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Vocational Education.

With reference to your letter of the 2nd Inst., No. 175397, I beg to say that the proposal to provide teachers' residences in connection with the schools at Middle River and Eskasoni has my unqualified approval. In fact, it was my intention to make such a proposition to the Department myself in the near future, not thinking that anyone else had the same thing in mind; but by reason of the necessities of the situation would be a little more comprehensive, and, therefore, I should include Bear River in the proposal.

I think that the primary object in providing these residences should not be altogether for the convenience of teachers, but rather as part of the educational establishment. My idea would be to have at least 2 acres of ground attached to each residence to be operated by the teacher as a miniature model farm, and, therefore, to serve as an object lesson and educating agency for the Indians who, experience teaches me, know little or nothing about the intelligent cultivation of the land; and until taught correct methods of agriculture by practical illustration, and by actual operations in which they may participate, they will hardly ever become successful farmers.

I beg to remark also that I do not approve of having the teachers' residences attached to the school house as an addition. I think the buildings should be altogether separate and apart from each other.

I beg to bring to your notice the need of a Teacher's Residence at the Eskasoni Reserve. The nearest place that is available at present for the teacher to secure accommodation is 4 miles distant from the School. The present teacher Mr. James MacNeil being a married man with a family finds it very inconvenient. And I also find it difficult to secure a suitable man to teach there under the present living conditions. As you can fully understand the white man is loath to take up his residence during a school term with an Indian family. So that the situation now is that he desires to have a teacher at Eskasoni. We must have some place for him to reside. I understand that there are funds provided in the estimates for such work as this and even if there were not I feel that the Department would be fully justified in going to work and building a Teacher's Residence there as the life of the School School depends upon it. The Deputy Superintendent General,

Tenders for the erection of a teacher's residence on the Eskasoni Reserve were receivable today. Two came to hand, one from Mr. S. H. Stevenson, Sydney, for $1865.00 and one from Mr. A. L. Mury, of West Arichat, for $1716.00.

This building is similar to the one erected recently at Middle River in which the contract price was $1450.00. Mr. Gheme's estimate for the erection of this building was $2200.00. You will thus see that Mr. Mury's tender, while higher than that received for the building at Middle River, is still well within the estimate and I think it is reasonable when it is taken into consideration that Eskasoni is not nearly so conveniently situated for the transport of material, etc., as Middle River.

The cheque which accompanied Mr. Stevenson's tender is not a certified cheque and he states that he was unable owing to lack of time to obtain such. Mr. Mury does
does not forward a cheque, but states that if his tender is accepted he will immediately forward one for 10% of the amount of his tender.

In view of the fact that this building should be erected this year I would recommend the acceptance of Mr. Mury's tender provided that his security cheque is forwarded at once.

Mr. Pedley,

Mr. Mury, contractor for the erection of the teacher's residence on the Eskasoni Reserve, writes the Department that he will require $500.00 more than his contract price if he is to go on with the building. He claims (1) that the delay in awarding the tender will put him to additional expense, (2) that the site selected is covered with trees and stuff that will have to be cleared; when making his tender he figured on a clear site, and (3) that he will have to put up a temporary house of the work people, as there is no accommodation in the neighbourhood of the school. His application for this increase is recommended by Rev. Mr. McDonald, Indian Agent at Christmas Island.

Tenders for this building were called for returnable on August 13th, last, and the memorandum to Council recommending the acceptance of Mr. Mury's tender was prepared on the 14th of that month. It was not until the 14th
14th ultimo that Mr. Mury was advised of the acceptance of his tender, two months having elapsed since the date of its receipt. The Department holds an accepted cheque from Mr. Mury for ten per cent of his contract price, which was $1716.00, and he has signed an agreement for the due performance of the contract. I think the Department could hold him to his contract, although he might be entitled to something for clearing the school site, but he should have made himself better acquainted with the position of affairs before making his offer. Probably the lateness of the season and the delays occasioned by bad weather will add to the expense of getting in the material. No doubt when his tender was made it was with the expectation of going on with the work during the summer and not in the beginning of the winter. J. D. Maclean Esq.,
My dear Sir:

In reply to your esteemed favour of the 3rd ult., No. 117552-5, I must say a barn 30 x 20 ft in size is sufficient to meet the present and future requirements of the property here. But on submitting the matter of building a barn the required size to builders, they claim it cannot be done for less than 7 or 800. I have however learned that the Chapel on the Reserve (which is replaced now by a larger one) is for sale. And upon examining it carefully I find it is 31 x 21 ft in dimensions. The soundings are heavy enough for a building double the size, of good sound timber also the rough boards. The walls and roof require to be re-shingled and the interior remodelled, according to plan enclosed. I will undertake to remove the said building to a proper location near residence. Purchase, Construct proper pillars of stone and cement or concrete under foundation; Re-shingle the walls and roof completely. Furnish the required doors and windows. Remodel the interior, with proper flooring of Plank. Stalls, Feeding alleys and loft overhead. Paint doors and window sashes. Grade the location for the sum of $425. I enclose you a rough plan of the arrangement desired. There will be ample space for five stalls, and a stable, also for ten or twelve cows hay.
I have this summer three milk cows and two younger ones which is the least number that should be kept to provide milk, butter and meat as well as to furnish manure for the quantity of potatoes and vegetables required, and save the cost of fertilizer which every year is not reliable.

I sincerely thank you for giving this matter your kind consideration, and if the above proposition meets your approval kindly report to the Agent, and under his authority and inspection I will buy the building at once and undertake to have it completed in accordance with the enclosed plan before the first of August.

Ever so grateful for your efforts in making this place more comfortable to myself and family,

Sincerely,

James McNeil

Sir,

Dear Madam,- With further reference to the subject of my letter to you of the 16th, inst., I beg to say that I visited Rev. A. R. Macdonald, Indian Agent for Eskasoni reserve, on Sunday last, and he informed me that influenza, which was epidemic recently among the Indians of Eskasoni, had quite subsided, and that regular communication with the place had been restored. You may, therefore, take charge of the Indian school at Eskasoni as soon as you possibly can, which I hope will be early next week.

With regard to the most expeditious way for you to reach Eskasoni, I would say: Make it a point to arrive by the Midland Railway at Truro in the evening, so as to enable you to take the night express from that point to Christmas Island, where you will arrive at 7 o'clock the following morning, barring unforeseen delays. This will give you at least ten hours of daylight to complete the remainder of your journey - a distance of about 12 miles from Christmas Island.

Father Macdonald, the Indian Agent, lives quite near the Railway Station at Christmas Island, and he expects you to call on him promptly, which I advise you not to neglect doing. He will direct you where to get a conveyance to take you to Eskasoni. You will find him a very kind man, and ready to assist you in any way he can. I have instructed him to furnish the teacher's residence at Eskasoni with a Cook Stove, a Bedstead, a Mattress, and a few chairs. You will have to supply yourself, whatever other items of furniture you may require.

I hope will be able to leave Berwick for Eskasoni early next week. All concerned are very anxious to have the Indian school there in operation again.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Reference the attached voucher No. 276 for $27.95 in favour of Wright's Limited, Sydney, N.S., I beg to state that a new bed has been needed in the teacher's room for some time. It was my intention however to wait until after the end of the fiscal year before recommending the purchase of a new bed. But it would appear that it became necessary and the Agent had same supplied. The payment of this account will be satisfactory after the end of the year.

Furthermore, I might say that the amount of furniture in the Teacher's residence at Eskasoni Reserve is very limited and the only chairs at the disposal of the teacher and her sister are a few kitchen chairs. I do not think that it would be extravagant to have a couple of inexpensive rocking-chairs supplied for their use, and I am sure if these are furnished the accounts can be held over until next month.

Ottawa, March 14, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing a voucher to the amount of $27.95 covering the cost of a bed, mattress and spring for the use of the teacher's residence at the Eskasoni Indian Day School. In reply I have to say that a cheque in payment will be sent when our funds for the next fiscal year are available.

Relative to the purchase of the above equipment, I have to say that, while this account will be paid, in future the local Indian Agent or yourself should obtain authority before incurring expenditures other than in cases of emergency. Mr. Agent McDonald has frequently made purchases without first receiving authority, and you should inform him that in future it is expected he will carry out the Department's requirements before incurring any expenditure.

Regarding the supplying of two inexpensive rocking chairs, I have to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of this equipment; the rendering of accounts covering the cost to be deferred until after the 1st of April, next. It is not intended that any expensive equipment be supplied. Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost should be forwarded in the usual manner.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

- The Director -

I wish to submit the following report on my recent visit to the Indian Agencies in the Province of Nova Scotia.

I also had an interview with the Medical Health Officer of Cape Breton County, re the health situation on the Eskasoni Reserve. He pointed out that we had considerably known active T.B. cases, and many suspected ones for which the province of Nova Scotia had no accommodation in their hospitals and sanatoriums. He stated that he received unfavourable criticism every time an Indian was admitted to a medical institution, because there was no accommodation available for the Whites and they resented Indians being cared for when they were denied admission.

He believes that the only solution for this problem is for the Branch to erect its own hospital or hospitals as the case may be.

Arrangements have been made to have all the Indians X-Rayed sometime during the late summer. This is going to be an expensive proposition since the Indians have to be transported to Sydney by bus. The best price the Agent could obtain from the bus company was $75.00 per trip and it may be necessary to make four or five trips to complete the job. Owing to the shortage of large x-ray film, small films will have to be used. Where trouble is noted, the Indians will have to return for a large plate.

It appears to me that Eskasoni would be the proper place for a small hospital and could very well give employment to a full time doctor. I was told that the Sisters of St. Martha are prepared to staff the hospital, and have suggested that when the teachers' residence is erected, it should be designed to accommodate the Nursing Sisters - all of whom should come from the same order.

G. Armstrong,
Welfare Division.

December 5, 1945.

Re: Temporary Heating, Principal's Residence,
Eskasoni Indian Agency, Nova Scotia.

With reference to your memorandum of the last instant and attached copy of letter dated November 24th from the Rev. Father Ross in which he requests to have an automatic pumping system installed for a temporary water supply in the new Principal's Residence at Eskasoni Chapel, we would comment as follows:

It is assumed that the installation is required not only to supply water to the boiler but also for the domestic supply to all plumbing fixtures in the building.

We have no information in this office regarding the source of water supply to which Father Ross refers, and as the feasibility of the scheme, apart from the question of cost, depends upon the volume, constancy and elevation of the water supply at the source, as well as the provision of electric current, to the development area, we have already instructed Mr. Roberts, by wire, to investigate and report on the matter immediately.

The cost of the pumping unit ($104.10) shown on the clipping which Father Ross forwarded, would, of course, be only a part of the total cost of the installation. Costs for labour and material in trenching, piping, insulation etc., must also be considered. This temporary equipment would be of no use when the permanent water supply system is completed. We have no assurance, of course, that either the pumping unit or the necessary piping and fittings will be available.

In a previous discussion on the matter with officers of the Indian Affairs Branch, they indicated that they were willing to leave the buildings unoccupied during the winter and in a recent letter from Mr. Roberts he states:

"The Indian Agent realizes the problems we have been up against in securing materials for the water line, and agrees that the buildings should not be occupied until water is available."

We do not consider that any damage is likely to be caused to the new buildings through lack of heating if they are properly closed up during the coming winter.

In regard to the well to which Father Ross refers, Mr. Sparks, who is familiar with the development area, states that it is doubtless of surface water origin and therefore the Department should take no responsibility as regards its purity.

With further reference to your memorandum of the 1st instant and the request from Rev. Father Ross for the above equipment, we have now received a wired report from Mr. Roberts furnishing data from which we are able to give further information on the subject as follows:

The well to which Father Ross refers is of surface water origin with a maximum (present) flow of 120 gallons per hour and an effective capacity of about 50 gallons. The well dries up in summer and there is no assurance that the flow will be constant or that it will not cease before the proposed general water service is installed next spring. A pipe line between the well and the pump in the basement of the residence would have a rise of about two feet and would require a trench excavation four feet deep to ensure against frost penetration. If rock were encountered at a lesser depth, the pipe would have to be boxed in and insulated.

Mr. Roberts estimates the cost of the installation as follows:

- Excavation of pipe trench and backfill $300.00
- 280 feet of 1" pipe with fittings and connections $90.00
- Wiring and installation, pump and tank $100.00
- Trucking and pipe laying $90.00
- Pump and pressure tank unit $110.00

Total estimated cost $690.00

It is hoped that electric current will be connected about the middle of January next, but there is no assurance of this.

In consideration of the facts stated above and outlined in our previous memoranda on the subject, and also in view of the probability that a temporary water supply would only be of use for three or four months, we are of the opinion that the purchase and installation costs of the unit would not be justified or economical.

RE Occupation of New Residences - Eskasoni Chapel.

I have for acknowledgement your letter of November 22nd suggesting ways and means to occupy the new residences this year. This matter is of paramount concern to us also and we have been debating ways and means to get into them as soon as possible after completion. Father Ross, Mr. MacDonald and myself are all very anxious for a change as none of us are at all satisfied living under the present circumstances.

For your information the builders (Chappells) have had Father Ross' hot water heating system in continuous operation over two weeks now. RE: Occupation of New Residences.

I acknowledge your letter of December 19th. As soon as the Chappells firm turn the residences over to your control then you have authority to move into them. This office should be informed of the date they are to be made available as well as the date on which they will be occupied.

as no doubt the frost has already gone into the ground two or three feet. Sirs:

On November 24, 1945, I wrote you in reference to the installation of a temporary water system in the Principal's Residence. I have not received a reply to my letter that courtesy would demand. I have heard indirectly, however, that this water system would cost too much. If you had been around here during the past few months and witnessed the money that was being wasted in a vain attempt to construct a water system, you would not consider the installation of the system that I petitioned for too great an expense. It was a source of scandal to the whole countryside and all political parties to see your Engineer in a very inefficient manner attempting to construct a water system. Now, the whole thing is discontinued for the winter and the drains are filling in with earth and will have to be reopened next summer at considerable additional expense. I ask is this good economy? If the job had been given to M.R. Chappell, Contractor, it would have been completed in 1945; he had sufficient pipe available and above all would know how to do the work properly and efficiently.

In view of the fact that you do not agree to grant my request for a temporary water system this winter, I am arranging to have water installed at the expense of our church or diocese, even if they have less money in funds than the Government of Canada. I plan moving into the new house within a few weeks, in order to keep warm during the winter months, although I have very little furniture to take with me.

Some time ago, I asked for a garage, through the local Indian Agent; and, as far as I am aware, nothing has been authorized yet. All I do know is that my car is out in the snow every day. Should it take all winter to erect a garage?
If I were working in a parish exclusively for the diocese and bishop, I would not experience as much difficulty in getting things as I have in working for the Indian Affairs Branch. You need not think that because you are erecting a house that you are doing more for me than is being done for the other clergy in the diocese.

I understand you are planning on having sisters come to Eskasoni. When a community of sisters come into a parish to undertake some special kind of work, such as to teach in schools, carry on hospital work, etc., they require the approval and authorization of the parish priest and authorities in the diocese. I want to make it clear to you just now that no sisters will come to work in Eskasoni, while I am Parish Priest here and your co-operation with me is as unsatisfactory as it is at present. I have the support of the authorities of the diocese in this matter and I will continue to get their support. If you are turning a deaf ear to my petitions now, you will do the same to the sisters later.

If you are determined, however, on having the sisters come here, and you co-operate with me, it will be necessary for you to consult the Mother General of the Order, and myself as Parish Priest, regarding their place of residence and working facilities. The plans that were drawn up previously are not satisfactory. What the sisters need and want will have to be granted in advance to their coming; otherwise, they will not come to Eskasoni. The Mother General and I are taking a united stand on this because you are giving evidence, in my case, of being unsatisfactory co-operators.

Yours very truly,

A. A. Ross,
Principal.
