Dear Father Ross:

I have hesitated to reply to your letter of January 8th until now in the hope that I would be in a position to reply helpfully and constructively.

I would not be altogether frank with you if I did not state that the statements and general tone of your communication are somewhat unusual. Such letters invariably cause resentment on the part of overworked officials who are doing everything humanly possible to assist our field staff, despite the critical and exacting times in which we are living.

You state, "On November 24, 1945, I wrote you in reference to the installation of a temporary water system in the Principal's Residence. I have not received a reply to my letter that courtesy would demand." The records before me indicate that your letter was received at this branch on November 26th and was sent forward to the Director of the Surveys and Engineering Branch on November 28th and by that branch referred to Mr. Roberts, the engineer of construction work at Eskasoni. An extract of his reply was sent forward to Mr. McKinnon, the senior administrative officer at Eskasoni on December 14th. A report dated December 10th was received by wire from Mr. Roberts of the Surveys and Engineering Branch and sent forward to us on December 11th, and Mr. McKinnon was advised of the decision reached by the department in a letter dated December 13th. An additional letter was sent forward to Indian Agent McKinnon dated December 27th, outlining departmental policy with respect to the occupancy and use of the recently constructed residences. It will thus be seen that despite the acute shortage of staff from which we are suffering, the representations made by you in your letter of January 8th were dealt with promptly and with despatch. The second paragraph of your letter, in fact,
indicates that you were already aware of the decision reached by the department with respect to the installation of a temporary water system.

I am anxious to outline in this letter as clearly as possible the exact position you occupy in the administration of Indian Affairs at Eskasoni. When the survey of conditions on Indian reserves in Nova Scotia was undertaken a few years ago by Mr. W. S. Arnell, certain representations were made to him by the Church authorities with respect to the creation of new agencies, the employment of full-time Indian Agents and particularly with respect to the operation of Indian day schools at Shubenacadie and Eskasoni. The Church authorities expressed the opinion that in view of all the circumstances the employment of a Priest as Principal at each school and the employment of nuns as teachers would expedite the policy of centralization and contribute to the material and spiritual advancement of the Indian population. These representations were re-submitted to the senior officials of the department by a group of Priests who had formerly acted as temporary Indian Agents, who had been invited to Ottawa to review the subject matter of Mr. Arnell's report, and particularly his recommendations with respect to the creation of two distinct and separate Indian Agencies in the Province. In this regard, it is only fair to state that in the operation of the residential school at Shubenacadie and in the selection of Priests to act as temporary Indian Agents, we have until now enjoyed the fullest measure of cooperation from the Church.

You were, as you know, nominated for the position you now occupy by the Bishop of the Diocese. Your position is that of Principal of the Indian day school on the reserve. You were classified as a temporary civil servant and employed on the understanding that you were subject at all times to departmental regulations. It has never been the policy or practice of the department to communicate with school principals or school teachers with respect to the administration of Indian Affairs on Indian reserves. The Indian Agent is the senior administrative officer and the official with whom we communicate on all matters relating to the welfare of Indians. To do otherwise would simply lead to endless confusion and misunderstandings. Your work as school principal will be inspected from time to time by the public school inspector, who will report to the department in due course. All matters relating to the welfare of the school should be submitted by you to the Indian Agent, who will in turn refer them, when he deems it advisable, to the department. The department at no time in its history has sought to interfere directly or indirectly with missionary work on Indian reserves.
This responsibility has always been borne by the Church and I can assure you in this letter that no official of the department, whether he be Indian Agent or engineer, will seek to dictate to you at any time with respect to the religious instruction you should provide at your Church or in the school, and, in this respect, you will be subject only to the wishes of your Bishop. As school principal, however, you will be subject at all times, as all civil servants are, to departmental regulations. You will not be permitted at any time as school principal to express opinions on engineering projects direct to the department, nor as school principal will you be permitted to express criticisms on the selection of contractors or on the adequacy or inadequacy of buildings. These matters are not your responsibility. It is only fair to you to state that you can only continue in our employment on this understanding. Your case in no sense differs from other Priests employed as part-time agents or as principals of day schools throughout the Dominion. All are alike - subject to the regulations now in force and seldom, if ever, fail to conform to established practice.

With respect to the construction of houses used as residences either for school teachers or school principals, the department, while always willing to receive helpful suggestions through the Indian agency, cannot and will not from time to time depart from its regular policy to meet the demands of any teacher or any particular group of teachers. The department has learned from experience that the stay of many of these teachers in these residences is comparatively brief and that their successors seldom agree with them with respect to accommodation, heating systems, water supply and other equipment.

The Government, therefore, in its wisdom has decided on standard residences, but it has never been our intention - nor is it our intention now - to compel any teacher or any group of teachers to dwell in the houses we establish. This is a matter for the teachers themselves to decide and I can assure you that no compulsion will be exercised by the Government with respect to the group of teachers on whose behalf you have written.

May I again emphasize that all matters relating to the operation of the school of which you are principal, including repairs or alterations to the school building and to the principal's residence, requisitions for supplies such as wood, coal, requisitions for textbooks, should be submitted by you to the Indian

.....Agent
Agent, who will, I feel sure, send forward promptly any representations or suggestions you may care to make to this department.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

P.S. - I am sending forward copy of this letter to Bishop Morrison for his information.

Reverend A. A. Ross,
Principal,
Eskasoni Indian Day School,

Dear Mr. Jones:

Re: Relocation of sewers,
Principal's Residence,
Eskasoni Indian Reserve.

You will no doubt recall our several discussions of the sewage disposal method in the above noted residence, and the necessity of immediate alterations. These alterations consist of:

(1) Relocation of drain pipe from wash basin in the first floor bedroom to the floor drain instead of the septic tank as at present,

(2) Relocation of drain pipe from basement laundry tubs to floor drain instead of the septic tank as at present.

(3) Relocation of stacks serving both bathrooms in such a manner that:

(a) The first stack, serving the kitchen sink and bathroom over the kitchen, shall leave the basement wall at an elevation allowing sufficient slope towards the septic tank.

(b) The second stack serving the other bathroom shall be broken at the elbow directly beneath the first floor joists and proceed to the wall at right angles, and, at highest elevation possible, tying into the first stack.

Your quotation of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to do this work has been accepted and I will be pleased to have your account made out in triplicate to: The Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA, upon satisfactory completion of the work outlined above.

It is understood that all necessary breaking and replacing of floor and wall concrete, excavation and carpentry work, both inside and outside of the building, shall be the responsibility of The Indian Affairs Branch.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
H.S. McKinnon,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

As you are probably aware the inlet of the septic tank serving the principal's residence was placed fifteen inches higher than the soil pipe leaving the building. This situation was unsatisfactory and had to be corrected.

Apparently the contractor was absolved of responsibility and Mr. Buck and Mr. Morris advised me to have the situation remedied. There were two ways of doing it.

(1) Leave the stack go out the building the way it was installed, dig up the septic tank, the pipe to it and the disposal bed behind it, and lower them all at least fifteen inches. If the laundry drain was to go in the septic tank it would have to be done this way.

(2) Take the laundry drain and the drain from a first floor wash basin, run them into the floor drain, and cut both stacks from the bathrooms and have them go out the wall at a proper height and change the line from the wall to the septic tank to correspond to the new elevation.

Following a series of discussions with the plumbers, Mr. Morris, the Engineer, the Contractors etc we decided the latter course was the most economical and possibly the best. With Mr. Morris's consent I have authorized H. R. Jones, the plumber who did, and is doing, all the plumbing & hot-water heating here, to make the necessary alterations at a cost of $100.00. I am attaching a copy of my letter to him.

I trust this action is satisfactory. As it stands now I will have to put a partition in the cellar, otherwise there would be a sewer pipe across his cellar at about head level. This will not be costly. Any further details could be had from Mr. Morris who is very familiar with the situation.

F. B. McKinnon, Agt.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Canada.

Because the main wall carries through there is now an area 6½' x 13' 2½" and 7' high being lost to use. Attention: Mr. Morris; Re hot water heating pipes, Teachers' Res.

You will recall our conversation with S.O. Roberts, Engineer, concerning the above mentioned pipes which strike one in the face while descending the steps to the cellar and his promise to move at least one of the pipes.

I have taken the matter up with him and could get no assurance that it would be done. The contractor now advises that they were instructed not to do it. I asked their General Superintendent if it could be done without impairing in any way the efficiency of the heating or interfering with present structure. His answer was that the offending pipe could and should be moved but that he would not recommend, or, at least could understand, why they would be unwilling to move the both of them. The second pipe, being further away, and a person descending would be correspondingly lower, would be alright unless one was over six feet tall but as you will recall, the first pipe is so low that an individual over five foot two or three inches will get a rap in the face. This seems very silly that an order would be given by an engineer not to have a small matter like this adjusted while the men and equipment were on the spot but it was done. This action is characteristic of his attitude ever since his arrival here.

I believe if the matter was brought to the attention of Mr. Mills or Mr. Buck it would shortly be attended to. As it is now there is nothing further I can do.

F. B. McKinnon,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to bring to your attention the fact that the plans for the Teachers' Residence and Day School being built at Eskasoni called for the installation of 90-gal. Domestic hot water tanks, heated by electric heaters totalling 3,000 watts, for each building.

The tanks have not yet been installed, but considerable work has been done on the wiring.

I think that you should be advised that the Eastern Light and Power Co., our only utility company, does not supply time clocks governing the amount of electricity used, unless an electric range is used in the building. These heaters, totalling 6,000 watts, will be connected to the meter at straight rates, and I firmly believe that they will cost the Department at least $80 or $90 dollars a month, which I consider excessive for the services obtained. Electric ranges are not practical out here as we have no way of communicating with the Power Co. when service is disrupted, and it is possible to be without current for long periods of time.

It is my opinion that neither of these buildings require the hot water capacity given them, but in any event, these tanks could be heated as well by jacket-heaters. As you know, these buildings both will be serviced by the janitor, and he could care for jacket-heaters as well as the furnaces.

F. B. McKinnon,
Indian Agent.

Re Teachers' Residence and Day School, Eskasoni Agency.

At my request the Mother General of the teaching order (St. Martha's) who will be in Eskasoni has prepared a list of residence and Domestic Science classes requirements. They are enclosed herewith showing thereon, in some instances, pencilled notations which are mine. Will you please scan these requirements and if all are acceptable to your office, please advise, returning the lists, and I will go to work on securing prices of a competitive nature from local firms.

Here I wish to say that when securing the furniture of the Principal's Residence I was allowed to get prices locally and upon your approval take delivery almost immediately. This resulted in a maximum of satisfaction and a minimum of trouble for all concerned. The purchasing authorities of the Dep't. of National Health & Welfare, Indian Health Services didn't allow this method when equipping the Nursing Station and are shipping direct. The result is that shipment is being made in dribs and drabs, the Agency truck is hauling stuff from the railway station 15 miles away that one could take in a wheel barrow. We are continually checking short shipments, part shipments, invoices, etc. and although the requisition was forwarded in November of 1946 and the nurse has occupied her quarters for two weeks she still hasn't a table to eat from. When they were unable to get several articles, I was authorized to procure same locally which I did almost immediately with the exception of a refrigerator which appears to be lost in transit. In view of the fact that we are very busy at all times and the truck as well, I trust it will be possible to follow the same method used when furnishing the Principal's Residence.

F. B. McKinnon, Agent.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Eskasoni Teacher's Residence, and Day Schools.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of April 22nd, 1947, and your notation thereon of the 26th instant, together with attached copy of Indian Agent McKinnon's letter, referring to the above, you are advised as follows:

An analysis of the hot water demand in the Teacher's Residence shows that the maximum demand should not exceed 75 gallons per day and that the normal requirement will be less.

On the basis of rates supplied to us by the Indian Affairs Branch, we have calculated that the maximum cost per month for the Teacher's Residence (assuming that 75 gallons of hot water per day is used) would amount to $18.68. A fair assumption of the average monthly cost would be about $15.00. Since the hot water demand in the School should be considerably less than the Teachers' Residence, we feel that an outside figure of $10.00 per month would cover the cost, or, an average of about $25.00 per month for both buildings.

It is pointed out that both tanks are equipped with aqua-statics, and the current is automatically cut-off when the tanks are heated to the correct temperature which, in addition to saving current, protects against overheated water, thereby preventing an undue formation of rust and scale in the tanks and distribution piping.

Jacket heaters could have been used at some saving in fuel, but it would be difficult to ensure that water temperature will be kept below the temperature required for protection against scale and rust. In any average period, it is felt that the saving effected by the use of coal would be of little importance.

The comments herein of course are based on the assumption that the school teachers will co-operate in keeping faucets closed when not being used in both buildings, and that hot water is not wasted.

Chief Engineer.

Re: Principal's Residence

I wish to refer to my letter of August 15 requesting permission to allow Rev. Fr. Ross, school Principal, to disconnect his Domestic boiler in the basement and place it behind the kitchen range heating it with a coil installed in the oil range. I would like to point out that in this case, at least, I think his request is justified. We have both tried to make the jacket heater work satisfactorily, but no luck. In addition we have the bother of kindling and coal which would be eliminated entirely if he were allowed to heat it from the kitchen range. Besides being more practical from his point of view, I believe it is also more economical from our point of view.

As stated before, he realizes that the excessive light bill is caused by the electric heater, and he is prepared to remove it and have the boiler change over done by a competent plumber at his own expense.

I would recommend that permission be granted.

F. B. McKinnon,
Indian Agent.

When drawing up the list of household requirements for the teachers' residence, I regret very much that I omitted a few essential articles and was misunderstood on another. When I asked for armchairs I meant the type that usually go with a three-piece Chesterfield suite. (I did not want the Chesterfield,—just the chairs). The quotation did not go through this office, so it was not until the articles were inspected and delivered that I saw that the armchairs quoted on were insignificant little pieces costing $5.00 each.

Mr. F.B. McKinnon, Indian Agent,
Eskasoni, N.S.

We have your voucher No. 1358 for $342.58 in favour of D.J. Bonnell, Limited. Your voucher reads "articles supplies for teachers' residence, Eskasoni, N.S." Before payment can be considered, we require an explanation regarding purchase of the following items:

(1) Juice Extractor - $3.95. There are several serviceable juice extractors that could be purchased for considerably less money.

(2) 12 Sieves @ $1.45 each. Why was it necessary to purchase this number of sieves for the teachers' residence?

(3) 10 saucepans, pint size. 10 wooden mixing spoons. Why was it necessary to purchase so many?

(4) 10 lemon squeezers at .20¢ each. We cannot understand why so many squeezers were required for the teachers' residence.

(5) 10 nests of mixing bowls at 1.40. What has been said regarding lemon squeezers applies also to the mixing bowls.

It is possible that some of the items on the account cover articles purchased for the domestic science class. In that event, a separate account should be forwarded for such articles.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
D J BONNELL LIMITED

November 18, 1947

Mr. W. M. Vincent,
Purchasing Division,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sirs:

We have your letter addressed to Mr. A.E. McPherson, who, with myself quoted the prices on the merchandise for Eskasoni Chapel. At the time we quoted you $290. on a refrigerator we felt that we would have one in which we could put through at this price. However, the next lot the models that we had in mind when they came through sold retail for $375. against the $319. originally.

You can readily understand that our cost on this refrigerator is higher than the price quoted you. We would like to make you the following offer. We will supply, and delivery to Eskasoni (1) 7 cu. ft. Philco Refrigerator at a price of $325. The original retail price of this machine was $398. We feel that $325. will just about cover our cost.

We hope that you will consider this, but if not we will take the loss of $35., and fulfill our contract. We appreciate the business you gave us in the past, and we figured a very low mark up on all merchandise that was shipped to Eskasoni.

We are leaving this matter to your good judgement as to what price you will accept this machine. Thanking you for your past favors, we remain,

Yours very truly,

D. J. Bonnell Limited.

With reference to the attached account for the services of a plumber, I wish to advise as follows:

The first charge of $39.48 was for changing over the hot water heating system in the Teachers' residence. Herefore, there was a 92 Imperial gallon boiler in the cellar, heated electrically by two immersion heaters, totalling 3000 watts. The bills, as you know, were excessive, and Mr. Morris, Inspector of Indian Agencies, advised that it be changed over to a more economical system. This was done by following the same procedure as used in all the other residences, that is; inserting a coil in the kitchen range. It is working satisfactorily, and the teachers now have hotter water and sufficient for their needs.

The second charge for repairs to the heating system in the R. C. M. P. residence was necessitated by the fact that one night during the past winter the Constable, on duty in Sydney, was unable to get home because of road conditions. A severe frost cracked two radiators in the cell room. The cell room is small and when the heat was on, it was found to be, if anything, too hot. I thought it better to replace the larger radiator only, which provides ample heat under all conditions. I trust that this is satisfactory.

The third charge was for repairs to the water line servicing the garage, which broke, for some unaccountable reason, underground.

F. B. McKinnon,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

Dear Sir,

Being teaching sewing and knitting to pupils in the Indian Day School here I should like to know if the school is entitled to the grant which is paid by the Department of Education for work done in Household Science.

I hold a Second Class High School Certificate (Licence) and a Trade Scholarship. I have taught knitting and sewing to the children for one hour every Friday afternoon since I began teaching in this school (September, 1937).

All the boys and girls over nine years of age have been taught to knit such articles as caps, scarves, gloves, mittens, and stockings. They have knit twenty-two dollars worth of yarn so far.

The girls have sewn ten dollars worth of material besides sewing materials which they have brought from their homes.
They have learned to do patching,
and also to sew and cut articles such
as aprons, sewing-bags, holders, blouses
and slips.

The Local Indian Agent, the Inspector
of Schools, and the Sewing Teacher of this
Province have seen all the work of
the children, and they approve of it.
Please let me know at your earliest
convenience if this grant shall be paid
for this extra work, so that I shall
continue this work which the pupils
find very interesting and which is
very, very beneficial to their welfare
in years to come as well as at present.
I also serve a hot lunch to the pupils
for three months each winter.

Thanking you in anticipation
of receiving an early and favorable
reply,

Yours Truly,

Dear Miss MacMillan:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the first instant and to state by way of comment that it is very gratifying to learn of the attempts you have made to promote vocational instruction at your school.

The Minister of the Department is particularly interested in this phase of educational effort and is constantly reminding us that the courses provided at Indian schools should be practical and vocational in character.

I have no knowledge whatever of the grant to which you refer in your communication. If you have in mind a provincial grant, your school of course is not eligible. The cost of operating Indian day and residential schools is borne wholly by the Dominion Government.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Miss Jessie MacMillan,
Teacher,
Eskasoni Indian Day School,
Eskasoni Chapel, N. S.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY.

Mr. Doucet and I have discussed the attached requisition from Indian Agent McKinnon for vocational equipment for the Eskasoni Day School.

As far as we know no definite arrangements have been made for a Manual Training teacher and we do not have any correspondence on file indicating if one of the Sisters are able to teach this subject.

In view of the above, I suggest that you take this letter with you when you go to Eskasoni and you can discuss this matter with Mr. McKinnon and the teachers and advise us on your return the items which you consider should be supplied.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

PP/HM.
Eskasoni Chapel, N. S.,
July 7, 1947

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

In addition to the above, I would like authority to pick up a quantity of wood screws of all sizes, small bolts, wood, if not available on the Reserve, glue pots, brushes and other supplies as needed from time to time.

F. B. McKinnon,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

In our school which has an enrolment of approximately 135 we have a number of children who, it can be readily seen, should have as much or more emphasis placed on extra curricula subjects as on the academic course of study. I have in mind children whose I.Q. is not very high and boys of 14, 15 and 16 who are doing grade five or six work. We have an average number of this type and I think they could well employ their time by doing Manual Training work.

I would like to inquire if any action has been taken on my Manual Training requisition forwarded to your office on July 5th, 1947. Although we are not prepared right now for a full-time Manual Training teacher, yet our present teachers are capable of at least directing the energy of some of our students into that type of work. I would like to be advised when I may expect some of the equipment ordered so that a start might be made in a small way. I would also like to know if it is the intention of Mr. Doucet to come down this fall to look over the situation with regard to this type of teaching in the two large day schools in Nova Scotia.

Ottawa, November 24, 1947.

Mr. F.B. McKinnon, Indian Agent,
Eskasoni, N.S.

We have your letter of the 28th ultimo with reference to manual training equipment for the Eskasoni Day school. It is noted from the last paragraph of your letter that you consider some work could be done by the present staff if they had some equipment.

We are ordering the supplies which we consider will be most useful and you may purchase materials for this class at a cost not exceeding $50.00.

It is not our intention to send Mr. Doucet to Eskasoni this fall. However, he will be sent about April of 1948 at which time he will review the whole situation with a view to deciding what action should be taken for the academic year 1948-49.

In the meantime, you should make inquiries with a view to ascertaining if a qualified manual training teacher can be secured for the academic year mentioned above. If a qualified man can be secured, his duties would commence on September 1st, 1948. Any information you may obtain in this regard should be forwarded for our consideration.

We are also communicating with the Director of Technical Education for the Province of Nova Scotia.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, November 24, 1947.

Dear Mr. Sexton:

We have recently completed a new four room school on the Eskasoni Reserve in Cape Breton. We propose to introduce manual training at the beginning of the academic year 1948-49.

We would appreciate it very much if you would keep this matter in mind and let us know the name of any qualified manual training teacher who might be interested in accepting employment with us.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. H. Sexton, D.Sc., C.B.E.,
Director of Technical Education,
Department of Education,
Halifax, N.S.

May 25, 1948.

Dear Mr. Ford:

Last fall we wrote to Mr. F.H. Sexton, D.Sc., C.B.E., with reference to securing a manual training teacher for our new Indian day school on the Eskasoni Reserve in Cape Breton.

In a letter dated November 29th, 1947, Mr. G.R. Sutherland, Instructor of Industrial Arts, wrote to us and stated that our letter to Mr. Sexton had been referred to him. At that time Mr. Sutherland stated that there was a serious shortage of licensed manual training teachers in Nova Scotia.

Is there any likelihood of our being able to secure one or two qualified manual training teachers for the academic year 1948-49? One of them would be required on the Shubenacadie Reserve, five miles from Shubenscadie, N.S., where we have a new four room school. The other would be required at the Eskasoni School.

Anything you can do to assist us would be very much appreciated. Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Heary
Superintendent of Education.

E.K. Ford, Esq.,
Director of Vocational Training,
Department of Education,
Halifax, N.S.

I attach hereto a letter received from our Domestic Science teacher, Mrs. Margaret MacDougall, relative to her needs for that part of the school basement allotted for the teaching of household economics. I quite agree with Mrs. MacDougall in that the room is rather drab and uninspiring and should be equipped with some of the requisites for the successful teaching of household economics.

I have asked Miss Ruth Binnie, who is the Supervisor of Home Economics for the province of Nova Scotia to come down and give me her recommendations. We were also favoured with an unexpected visit form Miss Sackville of the Department of National Health & Welfare, Nutrition Division, and the minimum recommendations of both ladies are embodied in Mrs. MacDougall's letter.

Mrs. MacDougall is doing an excellent job and is now engaged, along with her other work, in visiting the home environment of her pupils in order to better acquaint herself with the immediate needs of those of her pupils who will shortly be leaving formal instruction.

In order that you may have some idea of the cost involved I wish to advise that:

- The floor covering will cost approx. $400.00
- The tables approx. 75.00 ea
- Painting room (paint & labor) 100.00
- Refrigerator approx. 325.00
- Sewing machine approx. 60.00

A very rough sketch of the room was provided by Mrs. MacDougall but more accurate information could be gleaned from the blueprints of this building which must be
must be.....

available to you. You will notice that the sink is about fifteen feet from the stove and the hand basin is 28 ft. from the same. I am not prepared to recommend any structural changes but do feel that the minimum of equipment and furnishings as asked for in the attached letter, if provided, would bring our Home Economics Dept't. somewhat more in line with present Provincial standards.

I am prepared to procure any authorized equipment or furnishings, for this classroom. Will you kindly advise of your decision in this matter?

P. B. McKinnon,
Sup't. Indian Agency.

26, October, 1948.

Mr. F. B. MacKinnon,
Superintendent, Indian Affairs,
Eskasoni, N.S.

Dear Mr. MacKinnon,

Having completed six weeks of teaching in the Home Economics department of your school, I feel that I am now in a position to make some recommendations to improve the classroom. This I feel is absolutely necessary in order to give a practical as well as satisfactory course to the students.

First, we need covering for the floor. At present it is a drab grey concrete. May I suggest marboleum of pleasing design and colour.

We need six work tables to include drawer space for equipment. I should like to add here that built-in cupboards, with a working surface included in each unit, would be the ideal set-up. However, unfortunately, the walls are of concrete, and therefore, I believe that this plan would be very difficult, if not impossible to accomplish.

At present the walls are done in a brown and straw colour arrangement....very uninteresting. I feel that we should have a cheerful colour scheme that would be more in keeping with the home kitchen, which we aim to make our room represent.

A frigidaire is also a necessity. It would eliminate spoilage of food which must be carried over from day to day.

Lastly, we need another sewing machine. Our classes average ten pupils, and I find that one machine is inadequate.

I am enclosing a plan of our room as it appears at present. It is quite obvious that changes should be made with regard to location of sinks, etc. Accordingly, I should be glad to receive suggestions for same.

Recently, I have had the pleasure of having Miss Helen Sackville, Nutritionist, Department of National Health and Welfare, visit me in my Department. This gave me an opportunity of discussing our set-up with her. I am pleased to say that Miss Sackville thoroughly agreed with the recommendations which I am presenting to you, and, she feels as I do, that satisfactory results can not be achieved without adequate equipment and cheerful environment. I have also had Miss Ruth Binnie, Supervisor of Home Economics, Department of Education, Halifax, spend some time with me, and in her opinion it is very necessary that we make the change as suggested, in order that the teaching of Home Economics be a success.

Your advice on this matter would be greatly appreciated,

Respectfully yours,

(Mrs.) Margaret M. MacDougall.
Classes held in this room average ten pupils.

In reply to your letter, 50-1-11 (E.1) of July 26th, 1948, having reference to my requisition for yarn, I wish to advise that the Garment Club referred to is in no way connected with the adult women of this agency. It is a Club sponsored by the Provincial Department of Agriculture for the encouragement of club work among girls of school age. Its chief purpose is to teach the art of making their own clothing and the yarn requisitioned for amounting to $59.40 was to enable the children to make their own mitts, scarves and sweaters, as was done last year.

With reference to my requisition amounting to $203.86, this was made chiefly for the purpose of weaving by the school children. I have asked Miss Moodie for more of her surplus looms and was desirous of having a large number of our school girls learn to weave. If Miss Moodie can find additional looms to send here, I believe the requisition is not too high. If she cannot, this requisition could be reduced by one-third.

The reference I made to the possibility of some adults using this yarn is conditional upon my ability to interest a few of the members of the Homemakers' Club in the art of weaving. I do not think that the amount they would use would be very great, and since there is only a possibility of their using any of it, I would prefer not to attempt any division. If the Homemakers' Club uses any of it, a record will be kept and I will ask Welfare or the Homemakers themselves to replace the amount used.

With reference to your last paragraph noting that there are only 28 children from Grade Five up, please be advised that every girl in Grade Three and upwards did knitting last year. It should be remembered that although their scholastic attainments are not high, the majority of
of girls in grade three and four are older in years than the grades indicate.

I might point out that three of our girls left Grade six to marry during the past term and one in Grade four had to leave school before Christmas because of being pregnant.

F. B. McKinnon,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.

With reference to the attached voucher # 228 in favour of Stanfield's Limited, Truro, W. S., I wish to advise as follows:

In discussing this request with Mr. Yeary I advised that the yarn cost $1.05 per pound. This price was for a coarse yarn which the Domestic Science Teacher found was not suitable for her particular project. Our girls belong to a Provincial Garment Club and their year's work will be entered in Provincial Competition. The project this year is a skirt, sweater and blouse, -- the yarn I quoted on was too heavy and too coarse for this work. Our girls are weaving their own skirt material from this yarn, making it into skirts, knitting their own sweaters and making their own blouses.

When I realized the difference in the price of the yarn I reduced their requirements to an absolute minimum of 36 pounds, and at that, the total cost was $23.00 over the authority given. Under these circumstances I trust this will be paid as submitted.

I would like to know if your office is interested in seeing some of the work, when completed, of this nature done by the girls and following the Provincial Exhibition.

As you are aware we have no manual training teacher at Eskasoni. One of our teaching sisters attempts considerable with them in all the time at her disposal which is not extensive. She must flit from the manual training room to her classroom and back again. We have several large boys in smaller grades and we have a fair number in our senior room. We attempt to use up all the hardwood salvaged from old school desks etc which of course is slow tedious work for fifteen year old boys. Could your office consider giving me authorization to purchase a ½ H.P. motor for $30.00 and a drum sander at a cost of $25.00. This would speed up the preparation of old wood and the dressing up of the finished article and allow us to really attempt something by way of volume. I realize it is not possibly what you have in mind but we have not the sincere type of student who wants to have things perfect. Attention: Education Division.

For the past two years the Domestic Science Department, has been using a few army type, folding tables. These were purchased from the War Assets Corporation, by Welfare, and because of their instability etc., were not satisfactory.

Our Domestic Science Teacher would like to have a large work table, with drawers, and storage space for teaching equipment. This table should be large enough to accommodate ten pupils, with a working space two-feet-square for each child. She also would like to have, two long tables with drawers, for garment making, commonly called "cutting tables".

With our lumber and equipment, we are able to make these tables at Eskasoni. Although, our work-men are not skilled in cabinet making, I feel that they are quite capable, by proceeding slowly, in doing this work in a satisfactory manner. It would be very useful training for the Indians, and since we have the lumber and machinery, I think we should do it. Because of our inexperience in cabinet-making, and the necessity of proceeding slowly, I estimate that the total costs of three tables will be in the vicinity of $300.00. Will your office forward the Eskasoni Indian Agency Trust Account, an accountable advance of $300.00, (Three Hundred dollars), with which to pay labours, in the construction of the tables referred to.
Although this might appear large, I would like to bring to your attention, that the making of drawers and doors, installing of pulis and hinges, in a manner suited for classroom, is rather tedious and exacting work.

The tables will be very well constructed, mortised and glued, and chiefly of hardwood. These tables should be covered with marboleum, at an estimated cost of $40.00.

I wish to state in reference to the Indians settled at Indian Cove that there are sixteen families and an aggregate of forty school going children. Other families settle here for a portion of the year whose children need, for the time, increase the school attendance. Dear Sir,

Let me refer you to letter 9099q Oct. 16th, 1901. In that letter you asked me to forward you a requisition for the kindergarten supplies I needed. I did so and also a second requisition for the regular school material. I received this latter a long time after I asked for it. Up to date I have heard nothing further about the kindergarten material. Now Mr. McLean, will you please attend to the matter immediately? There is only a short part of the term left and it is the busiest part. I counted on having the material to
work with during the winter months. But still I should like to give the children a start in it. We are doing very good work this year, but it might be a great deal better, and you are handicapping us very much by delaying the improvements we need. We need a cupboard in the worst way. It is very discouraging to come in on Monday morning and find the copy-books and drawing-books all upset and marked over. The Indians hold service in the school on Sunday and, of course, there is no control over them. The cupboard would cost from $8 to $9. Nor will you please authorize the agent to have one built right away. When can I hear about the repairs?
In letter 227073—4 March 1875, you asked for an estimate. That has been sent in some time since and I am patiently waiting for a reply. You see, I cannot keep up the Indians about making their place tidy when the school is out of repair. If I could feel that matters would be improved on for next year, I should like to teach for another year; but if the school and yard are in their present neglected condition I cannot. The three boys are attending the Manual Training School at Picton regularly. One had brought home a model today with a perfect mark. We are very grateful to the Department for this concession.

Yours respectfully,

Wally Comstock

The Deputy Superintendent General,

With reference to Mr. Macdonald's application for an increase to Miss Cassie McDonald's salary sufficient to cover her railway fare to and from the Indian Cove school to Pictou, I beg to say that Miss McDonald has been teaching this school since August, 1902, and her present salary is $300 a year, being the amount paid the other teachers in the Province of Nova Scotia. Sir:

It is considered that certain instructions regarding the school at Indian Cove should be given you upon taking up duties as Indian Agent for Pictou County, N.S.

You should visit this school once each month, if possible, and assist the teacher in any way you can in encouraging a regular attendance of the Indian children of school age who are in good health. You should use your influence with the parents to see that their children attend regularly.

You should forward all requisitions of the teacher for classroom supplies to the Department. These requisitions should be made out on the forms for that purpose.

The quarterly returns of attendance should be prepared by the teacher at the end of each quarter, and certified by you, and forwarded to the Department, in order that payment of the teacher's salary can be made. For your information, I may say that Miss Gertrude McGirr, the present teacher, is in receipt of salary at the rate of $75 per month for the ten teaching months in the school year.

A supply of forms used in connection with school activities will be sent you under separate cover, and these you should keep on hand and supply the teacher as she requires them.

When, in your opinion, any repairs are required, you should forward a report to the Department, stating definitely the nature of the repairs and the approximate cost of same.

You should also make requests in due time for the fuel required.

Rev. R. C. MacGillivray,
Indian Agent,
Pictou, N.S.
No expenditure in connection with the school, unless of an urgent nature, should be undertaken without first referring the matter to the Department, and receiving approval.

If there are any outstanding accounts in connection with school activities since the death of the late agent, I shall be pleased if you will obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify and send to the Department, in order that payment can be made. In future all accounts for expenditure in connection with the school should be itemized, and in duplicate, and properly certified by you before being forwarded to the Department for payment.

It is hoped, as a result of the encouragement which you can give to the parents and the teacher, there will be much progress made in the educational work at the Indian Cove Day School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Considerable attention has been attracted by the work of the Indian School at Pictou Landing. The children, though naturally handicapped by their imperfect knowledge of English, are in a class by themselves where this disadvantage does not exist. This is particularly true of penmanship and drawing. At the recent Pictou County Exhibition and in the Grant Bros. Competition the awards made to this school were altogether out of proportion to its size. In the school competition at the exhibition they won 1st and 2nd place in grades 3 and 4 writing; 1st and 2nd in grades 2 and 3 drawing; 2nd in grades 4 and 5 drawing; 1st in grades 6 and 7 drawing; 1st and 2nd in freehand drawing, and 1st in landscape drawing. Of the four prizes offered by Grant Bros. for penmanship two went to this school. This is exceptionally good when it is considered that these prizes were competed for by the school children of Pictou, Antigonish and Guysboro Counties. The teacher, Miss MacGirl, and her charges are to be congratulated.

Dear Henry:

I have received your letter of October 26, with reference to Miss Gertrude McGirr, of Pictou Landing, Nova Scotia.

Miss McGirr has been employed as a teacher by the Indian Affairs Branch of my Department for a period of 39 years. She has given, as you say, long and satisfactory service. Unfortunately, the teachers of Indian day schools are not classified as permanent Civil Servants and do not come within the Civil Service Act. Therefore they are not eligible for superannuation. We are at present considering having a change made but this may take some time to come into effect.

It has been the practice of the Department to grant teachers of long and faithful service a sum equivalent to two months of their present salary.

Yours sincerely,

H. B. McCulloch, Esq., M.P.,
New Glasgow, Nova Scotia.

Dear Henry:

Miss McGirr has been employed as a teacher by the Indian Affairs branch of my Department for a period of 39 years. She has given, as you say, long and satisfactory service. Ottawa, June 10, 1947.

Dear Mr. McCulloch:

The Indian Affairs Branch has just circularized its day school teachers within the last week to ascertain how many of them are desirous of being included within the terms of the Civil Service Superannuation Act, for purposes of superannuation.

Unfortunately, in instances such as that of Miss Gertrude McGirr, it will cost a great deal for them to be included in the plan, due to the large back payment they will have to make (as provided in the act).

As you are doubtless aware, it has been the practice of the Department to grant teachers of long and faithful service a sum equivalent to two months of their present salary. It will rest with Miss McGirr to decide whether she wishes to qualify for superannuation as outlined above or whether she would wish a straight grant of two months' salary.

Yours sincerely,

R.J.M. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

H. B. McCulloch, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Ottawa, October 24, 1923.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the claim of Miss Gertrude McGirr, teacher of the Indian Cove Day School, for a balance of salary due her.

In reply I beg to say that the Department considers that the school year begins on September 1st and ends June 30th. On checking our records we find that Miss McGirr began duties at this school on September 1, 1907, at a salary of $310.00 a year. For the school year, beginning September 1907 and ending June 30, 1908, she should have received, approximately, $46.00 more than she was paid. The matter, however, has stood for such a length of time that the Department regrets that it is impossible to pay this sum now.

Each school year since September 1908, Miss McGirr has been paid her full yearly salary in quarterly instalments. However, the Department is desirous of dealing fairly with this teacher and in order to recompense her for the amount, as stated above, which she did not receive, it has been decided to increase her salary from $510.00 to $550.00 a year. This increase will date from January 1, 1924. It is hoped that this arrangement will prove satisfactory to Miss McGirr.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. J. D. MacLeod,
Indian Agent,
New Glasgow,
N. S.

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. Sir:

Sir: I enclose Vouchers for expenditure in connection with the repair of the School House at Indian Cove as authorized in letter dated 5th July 1898 No 9099½. The repairs were more extensive than I anticipated. Of course it was only a rough estimate that I gave in representing the matter to the Dept. The School House was in the worst condition; the walls resting on the ground, the roof and walls in need of shingling, no porch to the front, nothing done to the inside, and the beams too low. We had the house raised about two feet and placed on a solid stone muck base which took about eight cubic feet of stone. The windows were removed and replaced by new ones and four windows more than before. The posts and floor were so uneven and irregular that it took more time and material than if the building were put up anew. The beams stood about eight feet from the floor, and we had them raised to eleven feet. The wall all around is raised to the height of four feet from the floor. The rest of the walls and ceiling is lathed and plastered. A floor had also to be built and some of the brick in old floor were made use of. A porch six feet square was erected. As I had already overstepped the limits of the amount granted I could not have any more painting done than priming coat & the windows and finishing boards to the roof and corners.
Although it had been mentioned in my instructions contained in letter dated 5th July No. 9089½ not to exceed the amount allowed I could not very well order the work stopped nor left in an unfinished state and liable thereby to loss from the weather. I may state that were it not for the assistance given by the Indians the job would be considerably larger. They furnished the stone and took the other building material from River in their boats free of charge, and also gave quite a fair share of work. The work has been faithfully attended to by the carpenters. I have been with them almost every day.

We are still without any furniture for the school except long forms or benches. Writing desks are needed.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,

Rodrick McDonald
Agent
Pictou Co

Dear Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th inst. (no. 90992) also the receipt of all forms for the quarterly returns which you kindly sent me.

Your replies to my questions concerning the school term are all explicit with the exception of the last one. I can nowhere find either in the school returns or in the annual report of the department what date is considered the beginning of the present term.

You asked me to inform the department if their date at the opening of the school was correct. It is so. I am under charge on the 18th day of October. There is no other matter concerning my engagement which has not as yet been mentioned. There has been no written agreement as to what my salary shall be. I presume that will be arranged at the close of the quarter. I will speak of it now so that you can have leisure to give it attention.
Now in reference to the school property, I spoke of window blinds. We should require seven. They might be the ordinary string-roller blinds of some dark shade. The probable cost would be thirty-five (35) each.

Our school equipment is not nearly what we would like to have. When I opened the school, the seats were four rude benches with no backs. I succeeded in procuring seats and desks for 25 pupils! They are old desks which the school board here have discarded. The Indians treated them eight miles and cleaned and painted them. I undertook to buy screen-cloth at 50 cents and a can of paint at 50 cents for the desks. A third expenditure, I made was 30 cents for a firewood, making a total of 90 cents. I am well aware that these expenses were not authorized but I think you will see that they were a necessity. Quite so, no provision made for a teacher's desk. I have nothing but the rudest table and no seat. Another necessary article is a brown. And lastly I have to call your attention to the fact that there is immediate need for provision to build
an outhouse. The probable cost of a rude building of the kind would be from $200 to $300. I take pleasure in writing you about these matters as I expected the Agent, Rev. Mr. Donald would inform you. He lives some distance from here and I have little opportunity of seeing him. I am extremely sorry to take up much of your time, but in this case it is unavoidable. So far the school has been very satisfactory. The children are bright and the attendance is good.

Thanking you for your kind attention,

Remain

Your respectfully,
Nellie A. Connolly

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

July 4th, 1923.

MEMORANDUM

Reports have been received from the Agent and the Public School Inspector during the past two years regarding the condition of the school building at the Indian Cove Bay School (Nova Scotia).

Our Agent, Rev. J. D. McLeod, New Glasgow, N.S., has reported regarding the repairs required. These would include the reshingling of one side of the building and repairing the other side, also painting both inside and outside. The Agent estimates that the cost of the repairs would be between $450 and $500.

The Public School Inspector in his last report stated that the school house is a nice looking building, but cold in winter. He recommends that the walls, which are clapboarded, be stripped on the north and west sides and shingled over heavy paper.

There are 21 children enrolled, with an average attendance of 13. The building was erected in 1913.

I would recommend that our Agent be given authority to have the repairs required carried out. The Agent to make the purchase of the material required after obtaining competitive prices, and the work to be performed by day labour under the charge of a competent foreman.

Superintendent of Indian Education.
Ottawa, July 6th, 1923.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo, regarding the repairs required to the Indian Cove Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the necessary repairs being carried out to place this building in good condition. The clapboards should be stripped on the north and west sides and shingled over heavy building paper. The other sides of the building should be repaired where required, and the building should then be painted both inside and outside.

The work is to be performed by day labour, under the charge of a competent foreman. The regular scale of wages for the locality will be paid. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, for the labour employed should be kept by you. A supply of forms for the purpose are enclosed herewith.

You should make the purchase of all shingles, building paper, nails, paint, etc., and arrange to have these supplies delivered at the school. Before making the purchase, you should obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers, and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting you the lowest price. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the material used. A memo should accompany the vouchers showing the names of the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted. The time sheets for the labour should also be certified by you, and forwarded in duplicate.

The above repairs should be completed during the present summer holidays, in order that the school may be placed in a satisfactory condition before it re-opens in September next.

We note that you estimate the cost of this work to be approximately $500, which includes the material and labour, and this amount should not be exceeded.

The Department will leave this matter in your hands to make the best arrangements, and at the lowest possible cost. The work should be completed to your satisfaction.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Extract from Report of Inspector Macdonald on the Indian Cove Day School - dated April 30th, 1926.

There are two buildings, both belonging to the Government - the present occupied one and the old one in disuse. The latter is in bad condition. The former has leaks on the South roof; the shingles on roof of porch are coming off; a new back door is needed and both front and back steps need repair.

Ottawa, May 5th, 1926.

Rev. Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Indian Cove Day School, states as follows regarding the condition of the buildings:

"There are two buildings, both belonging to the Government - the present occupied one and the old one in disuse. The latter is in bad condition. The former has leaks on the south roof; the shingles on roof of porch are coming off; a new back door is needed and both front and back steps need repair.

The outhouses are none too good and at present are in a filthy condition, being used indiscriminately by pupils and others. In fact, new ones with locks should be provided".

I have to request that you will furnish a report regarding these buildings. As far as the Department is aware, there is only the building used for school purposes and the toilets in connection with this school. You should furnish full information as to the buildings referred to, and the work that is necessary to place them in good repair, and the approximate cost of same. This information you should furnish at an early date.

Regarding the outhouses, I have to request that you will arrange to have them thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good, sanitary condition. You should provide locks for the doors, the keys of which should be in the care of the teacher. No unnecessary expense should be incurred by you in having the outhouses cleaned, and when the work has been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. It is hoped that you will be able to give this matter your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLeod,

Miss MacDonald, travelling nurse for this Department for the Province of Nova Scotia, has strongly recommended the serving of a hot meal to the pupils of the Indian Cove Indian Day School each day. She states that such meals should consist of hot soup or broth with biscuits, milk, cheese, sugar and cocoa, and that the preparation and serving of same in the school would serve a very useful educational lesson. Sir:

It is considered that certain instructions regarding the school at Indian Cove should be given you upon taking up duties as Indian Agent for Pictou County, N.S.

You should visit this school once each month, if possible, and assist the teacher in any way you can in encouraging a regular attendance of the Indian children of school age who are in good health. You should use your influence with the parents to see that their children attend regularly.

You should forward all requisitions of the teacher for classroom supplies to the Department. These requisitions should be made out on the forms for that purpose.

The quarterly returns of attendance should be prepared by the teacher at the end of each quarter, and certified by you, and forwarded to the Department, in order that payment of the teacher's salary can be made. For your information, I may say that Miss Gertrude McGirr, the present teacher, is in receipt of salary at the rate of $75 per month for the ten teaching months in the school year.

A supply of forms used in connection with school activities will be sent you under separate cover, and these you should keep on hand and supply the teacher as she requires them.

When, in your opinion, any repairs are required, you should forward a report to the Department, stating definitely the nature of the repairs and the approximate cost of same.

You should also make requests in due time for the fuel required.

Rev. R. C. MacGillivray,
Indian Agent,
Pictou, N.S.
No expenditure in connection with the school, unless of an urgent nature, should be undertaken without first referring the matter to the Department, and receiving approval.

If there are any outstanding accounts in connection with school activities since the death of the late agent, I shall be pleased if you will obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify and send to the Department, in order that payment can be made. In future all accounts for expenditure in connection with the school should be itemized, and in duplicate, and properly certified by you before being forwarded to the Department for payment.

It is hoped, as a result of the encouragement which you can give to the parents and the teacher, there will be much progress made in the educational work at the Indian Cove Day School.

Reverend Sir:-

I enclose herewith Departmental cheque No. 3201 for $76.60, drawn in your favour to pay labour employed in connection with the painting of the Indian Cove school. Your labour return calls for a total of $68.60, but you apparently have made a mistake in reckoning the amount due to the men employed. Fifty-four hours at 35¢ an hour amounts to $18.90. With this correction the return amounts to $76.60. I note that you asked to have the cheque made out in favour of Chief Matthew Francis, but I have to point out that it is necessary to have the labour return signed by each man employed in the space provided for same under "Received payment" to show that each man has received the amount of money due him. This is necessary to meet the requirements of the Auditor-General. Each signature should be witnessed by third disinterested party.

One copy of the corrected labour return is also enclosed herewith. Kindly see that the men are paid and have them sign the labour return as instructed above and return it to the Department, as it will be required as a voucher for the Auditor-General.

In future, do not have labour returns signed by men employed until you have paid them. When an expenditure is authorized and you have to pay labour, it is in order for you to ask for an advance cheque, stating the amount, so that you can pay the men employed and have them sign the labour returns. Of course, if it is only a small expenditure, you can submit a voucher in favour of the person employed, and it will be paid direct by the Department.

A new stove is needed or, at least, a new fire pot for one. It is badly cracked all around.
Ottawa, October 15, 1931.

Sir:

The Provincial School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Indian Cove Indian Day School, states that a new stove is needed or, at least, a new fire pot, as the present stove is badly cracked all around.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding the need for supplying a new stove. Please take this matter up with the local Indian Agent, and state if the present stove could be repaired and the approximate cost. If not possible to make satisfactory repairs, you should state the cost of supplying a new stove. Please give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

C. J. McNeil, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Antigonish, N.S.
Ottawa, October 20, 1931.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 14th instant, I have to say that the Department will approve of the serving of a hot lunch to the various Indian schools in your inspectorate, the same as was done last year. The schools at which this lunch was supplied to the pupils were as follows:

- Easkasoni, Indian Cove (Pictou Landing)
- Sydney, Afton,
- Whyecocomagh, Salmon River.

The supplies for the lunch should be of the same type and approximately in the same quantities as last year. You may inform the various agents, arrange with them to purchase the articles and have the teachers start the serving of the lunch from the middle of November, next. They may continue serving lunch to the pupils at these schools until the end of April, 1932. All expenses in connection with the purchase of the supplies required should be kept as low as possible. Itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded, covering the expenditure incurred in this connection for each school, separately.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

G. J. McNeil, Esq.,

Sir:

In reply to your letter No.58-I-5 of October 15th, 1931, I beg to state that I have examined the stove in the Indian Cove Indian Day School and must report that it will be necessary to install a new stove. Furthermore, I beg to report that repairs such as new locks are required for both doors of the school also a few panes of glass. $12.00 should be sufficient to have these necessary repairs effected please.

Sir:-

I would refer you to your letter No. 58-I-5 of Nov. 10th, 1931, in which you authorized an expenditure of $45.00 for a new stove of the air-circulator type for Indian Cove Indian Day School.

At present there are two stoves in this school and it has been found that the better one of the two will also have to be replaced next year. Now one large air-circulator could heat this school, would eliminate one stove and many yards of stove pipe. Therefore it is considered expedient to put in a large air-circulator now and make one job of it. There would also be a saving on fuel. One large enough to heat the school would cost about $75.00 installed. Instead of an allowance of $45.00 as granted would you kindly allow $75.00 for this purpose please.

Your obedient servant,

Some of this annual expense for repairs to windows, doors, locks, etc., might be saved if a fence were built around the school grounds to prevent the boys and young men from congregating at the schoolhouse during out-of-school hours. MEMORANDUM:

Indian Cove Day School (Pictou County).

Teacher: Miss Gertrude McGirr.

This building is in rather a poor state of repair, and requires painting both inside and outside. The shingles on the roof need patching, the steps need repairing and a new door is needed on the school. Three panes of glass are also required.

The teacher asked for the following tools, as she is making an effort to teach some manual training: A bench saw, claw hammer, 3 chisels (small size), a plane, a small square, screw driver, nail set, brace and a few bits, 1 fret saw, 1 pail, and a book on manual training.

The teacher has also asked for some material for sewing.

A new out house is required at this school.

Regarding the painting, I asked some of the members of the Band if they would take a contract for doing the work and they said they would. Rev. Father Johnston will, in due course, send in the tender. We were to buy the paint and the Indians would do the work. I, of course, stipulated that I did not know whether the Training Division would have funds for this work or not.

I found that there were 27 children on the roll and an average attendance of 24 to 25.

Miss McGirr has taught for thirty years and I am sure she is performing very good work on the Reserve. She lives in New Glasgow and goes back and forth every day.

General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

On a separate sheet you will find in Fig 1 a rough sketch of the present arrangement of the heating system in Indian Cove school. In Fig. 2 you will also find a proposed new disposition and for which I am asking permission, for the following reasons:

Under the present system of heating an annual purchase of stove pipes has to be made, because they rust during the summer in spite of all precautions being taken to prevent rusting. The stove pipes are hung in the school room on wire, (about 35 ft. in all), Besides the bad appearance of the arrangement, it may not be the safest method.

With the building of a new chimney outside the building as shown in Fig. 2, it would do away with the buying of stove pipes every year, the appearance would be better and the heating system would be safer.

This proposed chimney would be about 28' high. Size: 12" x 8", with lining inside. A foundation of cement would also be necessary. The total cost according to Mr. Shackley of New Glasgow, who is a brick layer, would be between $90 and $95. These figures include labor, accessories, etc., etc.

Should this plan be not acceptable, kindly give me authorization to buy 12 links of stove pipes at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

Indian agent.

Dear Sir:-

I beg to inform you that during school vacation about 18 or 19 panes of glass have been broken with stones at the Indian Cove school. The R.C.M.P. of New Glasgow have been informed of the fact and are now conducting an investigation after I conducted one myself without results. I doubt that they will find the culprit. I firmly believe that the above mentioned fact is the result of plain devilment on the part of some Indian boys (probably not going to school) but it is extremely difficult to find out who are the guilty ones.

I must confess I am at a loss as to devise plans to prevent such future occurrence unless the Department issues a stiff warning to the Reserve as a whole that if such a thing happens again, drastic measures will be taken. I shall gladly convey the message.

Hoping an early reply re. this matter with suggestions as to what course to follow, I remain,

Your obedient servant,

Rev. E. Chiasson,
Indian agent.

P.S. School starts on Sept. 2nd and these panes will have to be replaced. In order to show that the Dept. is not too readily prepared to replace them, it might be a good idea to replace them some time after school has started.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill

An inspection of the Pictou County Agency was made this date and Rev. E. Chiasson, Indian Agent, interviewed.

SCHOOL

The school building is neat and adequate for the Reserve. The roof I am advised is leaking badly and should be reshingled. It is difficult to understand this leaking as the present shingles are not old and look quite serviceable. Due to the caretakers absence the interior of the school was not inspected. Father Chiasson assures me the leak is not from the ridge cap or flashing would indicate the present shingles being poorly laid. I would recommend that an experienced roofer be requested to report on the condition of the roof, and if necessary, the roof be reshingled. Three windows have been broken and will require replacement. Two outside doors also require to be rehung with possibly new frames at an approximate cost of $15.00.

OTTAWA, Ont., Canada.

Re: Indian Cove Day School,
Pictou Landing, Nova Scotia.

Reference to your letter of June 7th last respecting the captionally noted Day School which is urgently in need of interior and exterior repair.

On the 12/6/49, in company with A. M. HAWKINS, a competent builder and contractor, a patrol was made to the Indian Cove Reserve, where the Day School was examined. This building, which is of wood frame construction is 54' X 24' X 14' post. There is a concrete foundation under the whole building and is in good condition. However, the main building is in such disrepair that a lot of material has to be replaced. The roof which was covered with wooden shingles is completely gone as are the underneath rough boards. One side wall and one end wall will have to be shingled. Outside doors have to be replaced, some of the window sashes are rotten and they also have to be repaired.

Attached hereto you will find a labour contract submitted by Mr. HAWKINS in the amount of $1,145.00 which to my mind is a very reasonable price for the work that is to be done. This figure includes all outside and inside rough and finish carpentry, painting the outside and inside two coats and repairing the school desks (teacher and pupils).

Most of the materials can be supplied Con. Sheet # 2.
Re: Indian Cove Day School,
Pictou Landing, Nova Scotia.

from stock on hand at a reduction of current market prices. A list of these materials is also attached hereto with an estimate of the cost in each instance. To this figure can be added the cost of truckage, approximately $67.50 if the Agency Truck is used.

Should the contract of Mr. HAWKINS be accepted, periodic inspections can be carried out by Harry B. MacDonald, our outside foreman, thereby eliminating the necessity of another building inspector being sent here or hired to oversee the work.

May we be advised at your earliest convenience what your decision is in respect to these repairs?

(H. C. RICE) Superintendent,
Shubenacadie Indian Agency.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

The Indians of Malagoo badly handicapped for want of school and a house in which to meet. There are upwards of 20 children who could attend School. From my experience, I do not see tend that that number would attend on an average. Indeed whenever they approach me on the School question, I tell them that School would be no use to them. They would not send their children anyway away. They promised faithfully to make their little ones go to School if you established one, the poor people have a right to School privileges and they ought to have a chance to teach their children. They tell me that many would come to Malagoo if there was School on the Reserve. To get the Indians from Sydney and other towns would be, indeed, a good thing, though I for one do not want here them among those there. However the most good to the poor people must be the Motto, What say you about the School? It is a crying need.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 1st ultimo, I have the honor to advise that I visited both the Malagawatch and Sydney Indian reserves on the 24th and 25th of August respectively, and as a result of my visits I have the following report:

The number of families permanently resident on the Malagawatch reserve is less than the total population shown; fifty-three and the number of children of school going age twenty-one. I was informed at Malagawatch that two other mission families having no permanent place of abode at present would settle on that reserve as a result of the establishment of a school there, because the situation otherwise was the most desirable to them. These two families would add four to the number of children of school going age already on the reserve. The Indians whom I interviewed manifested a deep interest in the establishment of a school, which I sincerely hope will be accomplished.

I am very partial to school privileges and facilities, and to secure them in some particular case might be dispensed by greater lengths than the circumstances would justify warrant. But I submit that, in this age, and particularly in this country any community having upwards of twenty children who should be receiving an education, in the elementary branches at least, ought to be provided with a school; and therefore, I have no hesitation in recommending the establishment of one at Malagawatch, as applied for by the Agent-Head.
Sir,

The Indians of Malagawatch, Shawnee, &c., &c., are clamouring for the establishment of a school on their reserve, and I beg leave to enquire what the prospects are in that regard.

Mr. John Jac, captain of the Malagawatch band, who came to see me a few days ago, states that several families of Micmacs now living in the vicinity of North Sydney, but formerly residents of the reserve, would welcome it if a school were in operation there.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 27th ultimo, No. 315278/2, I regret not being able to report favourably with regard to the night school opened some months ago at Malagawatch for the benefit of the adult young Indians of that place.

Speaking to Mr. Arsene Burns in May, I notified him that I would visit Malagawatch again before the end of the quarter to inspect the night school conducted by him. Accordingly, at 5.30 on the evening of June 27th., I went to the school, but found it closed. Presently, however, Mr. Burns presented himself, and I inquired why his night school was not in session. He answered that it had just been dismissed, saying also that he thought the hour was much later, and blaming his timepiece for deceiving him. I then asked if he could re-assemble, without much trouble, the night scholars who "had just been dismissed", or some of them, so that I might have an opportunity of seeing what was being done. He said he would be glad to do so, and in a very short time several children presented themselves in the school room. But I soon discovered, to my surprise, that they were the pupils attending the day school also, and Mr. Burns acknowledged such to be the case.

From all I could learn on that occasion, it would seem that those for whom the night school was intended, have not been taking advantage of it; and I very much fear that they are not likely to improve the opportunity in future.

The objections to opening the Malagawatch School before the 2nd of January are fully set forth in my memorandum of the 1st of February last, turned out on this file. Sir,

In reply to yours of the 12th inst., No. 315275-1, I beg to say that apparently you are not conversant with the conditions that exist on this reserve. From the census it would appear that there are a number of children of school age in the vicinity of the school, and that they remain on the reserve. Now this I can assure you is not the case. The Indians here are very nomadic in their habits. They remain at home a couple of months in the winter and then they move to North Sydney or Sydney and build camps and stay there until they can find work to do.

When Mr. Boyd came out as official agent last spring a number of families came back here and as a matter of course Mr. Boyd saw a splendid opportunity of having the children take advantage of going to school and ordered him to keep the school open. I was of the opinion that Mr. Boyd was cognizant of my arrangements with the Dept. However, he being my superior I thought it best to obey his orders. There was in my humble opinion no other course open to him, so he is always anxious to have the children brought under school influence.
influence. So I wrote the school open in good faith, and when I found that my salary was not forthcoming I can assure that it has been due me for a great deal of trouble and worry. A night school has been conducted on the Malagawatch Reserve for the last two winters. Last year the enrolment was 9 and the average attendance was 6.
