Memo,

Re Malagawatch School.

School was closed on May 31st, 1913.

On November 13th, 1913 the Agent, Rev.D. MacPherson recommended that Mr. Frank Cabot, an Indian, should be appointed teacher.

Rev D. MacPherson, in his letter, stated that Cabot had attended school regularly, and as he was the only son of a widowed mother the position would be a great benefit to him.

In official letter dated December 1st, 1913, the agent was notified as follows:

"You may appoint Mr. Cabot to the position of teacher of this school for the winter months, salary to be at the rate of $30.00 a month. It must be understood, however, that this appointment is only for the one term."
Memo—— Mr. Scott.

The total population of the Malagawatch Band according to the last census, is, only, 27.

The school has been carried on for some years, during the winter months. Night school classes were also held.

It was closed on May 31st, last. The teacher, who had charge of the school up to that time, when sending in his resignation on November 16th, last, suggested that it would be greatly to the advantage of the Indian band there to have the school kept open for at least the five winter months. Rev. D. McPherson, the agent, recommended the appointment of a young Indian, named Frank Cabot, stating in his letter that Cabot had attended school regularly, and as he was the only son of a widowed mother the position would be of great benefit to him. The agent was informed on the 8th of December that he might appoint Cabot for the winter months, salary to be at the rate of $30.00 a month and that it must be understood that the appointment was only for one term.

Cabot has no professional qualifications but is teaching under permit. It could hardly be expected that a qualified teacher could be found willing to take charge of this school at the remuneration offered and for so short a period.

As the term, only, closed on the 31st ultimo, the quarterly return has not yet been received. The agent's report on this school for the month of March shows an enrolment of 7 with an average attendance of 4½. In reporting on the school the agent says:

"With Mr. Frank Cabot, Indian, of the Whycocomagh Band, in charge of this school for this quarter I think conditions are satisfactory. Of course, the young man is not qualified to teach in our..."
in our provincial schools but I am of opinion that he is doing better work with these few backward children than a qualified teacher could do. He knows the language of the children and he can give them the English of their words and thus avoid the necessity of teaching an unknown language through an unknown medium. Prospects are good for fair results."
Extract from the annual report of Supt. A.J. Boyd.

I am disposed to particularize in the case of Frank Cabot, a young Indian, who has charge of the school at Malagawatch, Inverness County. His education is limited, but, in my estimation quite sufficient to meet the requirements of the position he occupies. He is doing conscientious work and on the occasion of my visit to his school recently his pupils acquitted themselves very creditably under examination in Reading, Writing and Arithmetic. One thing which appealed to me and which was in contrast with my experience in some other and more pretentious schools, was the fact that his pupils understood well what they were doing. This I attribute to his being able to explain to them in their own language the subject and the sense of each lesson and each exercise.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the letter from Mr. Gallant asking for information as to whether there are any prospects of the Indian School at Malagawatch being opened in the near future I beg to say that this school was closed last December on the understanding that it was not to be re-opened during the winter months. The attendance at this school has been hardly sufficient to justify its being continued. During the last six years it has fallen off from an enrolment of 20 to 9, but to make up this number the return shows that there were three children five years of age and under and one over sixteen. I would also suggest keeping the school in session the year round, barring the usual vacations, if only, as an experiment for one year. Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 15th inst., I would say that probably Mr. Macneil, Public School Inspector, shares the idea entertained by others, especially by those in touch with day schools generally in Nova Scotia, that the attendance of pupils at the Malagawatch school should be better in winter than in summer, as I believe is the case in all Indian communities, and, therefore, that if it is thought desirable to have this school in operation during the summer, there should be no question about keeping it open in winter, when results on the score of attendance would almost certainly be more satisfactory.

I regard the prospects for a decided improvement in the school attendance at Malagawatch as not very encouraging. I cannot see that conditions there warrant a larger average attendance than six at any time of the year, because the pupils are not in sight, and it seems evident that some few years must elapse before any change for the better in this respect may be looked for.

Should a development of circumstances in the near future make the school situation at Malagawatch more promising, I shall duly bring the fact to the attention of the Department.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, in connection with the dates between which the Whycocomagh and Malagawatch Schools should be operated during the coming academic year.

While it is true that last year these schools were allowed to open in September and close in January, this privilege was granted to very few schools. The whole question of the dates during which the schools should be operated has been very carefully considered from all angles, and it has been decided that all Indian day schools should open October 1, 1941, and close on June 30, 1942.

In reviewing the returns, I find that in the March quarter of 1940 the enrolment at the Malagawatch School was 12 and the average attendance, 10; in the March quarter 1941 the enrolment was 12 and the average attendance, 11.

At the Whycocomagh School, in the March quarter of 1940 the enrolment was 50 and the average attendance, 29. At the same school, in the March quarter of 1941 the enrolment was 28 and the average attendance, 15.

From the figures just stated, it is evident that the closing of these schools for the month of January 1941 did not have any advantageous effect on the attendance.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Last week we visited Malagawatch reserve, that has been closed for some time. There is a fair school there and I wished to estimate what could be done with it. This is a problem as the reserve is so far out in the woods that it would not be of value for us to remove the building for our own purposes. I visited two school sections nearby thinking that possibly they would consider a purchase but they both have good schools. I shall get in touch with the Inspector of Schools for that County regarding the matter.

There is only one factor that may be a hindrance to selling the school and that is that the people are afraid to make use of it as it may contain tubercular germs. There are a few houses on Malagawatch reserve but we may tear them down and burn them. This reservation is not good, the land being poor and most of the lumber removed. If I can get a school section to remove the school, which is now an eye-sore out in the woods, I shall do so; if not I will dispose of it in the most economical manner.

J.A. MacLean,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

Sir, I am glad to receive of your letter No. 254014-1 dated January 31st, together with statement enclosed under separate cover.

In your official letter of Dec. 6th, No. 254079, it was stated that the Dept. had decided to allow me pay for the month of June and for the September and December quarters, etc., which I considered only right.

However, while I am agreed to the remuneration for 2/3 months of the year for the December quarter, I am certainly entitled to more remuneration than for seventeen days and twenty-five days respectively for the month of June, and for the September quarter as follows: during the month of June according to the regulations of the Dept., which have been sent to me through the Indian Agent, I am entitled to payment for the holidays (King's Birthday) June 4th and during the ensuing 4 days there was no attendance at school, owing to the prevalence of the common measles in the reservation; in a word, the school was closed for the want of attendance, so that I feel justified in claiming payment for the full month as per your letter of Dec. 6th.

Ditto with the September quarter, with regard to the mid-summer holidays and Labor Day, as well as for Saturday and Sunday, I am entitled to payment of salary for
for the full quarter, as I do not come under the heading of proper periods, like if I had been here to begin duty after the midsummer holidays. I have obtained teaching regularly, and had I known that I would not be paid for full time as usual (I was unemployed during the new summer holidays) I could have taken advantage of another situation that was offered to me, but preferred instead to keep on teaching in good faith, and hope that the Dept. will decide favorably towards sending me off for the balance of my claim for having continued to teach school in Malagash. For the month of June I claimed in $33.33 and Sept. $100.00

Received Cheque $166.66

So that I feel justified in claiming fifty dollars $66 ($50.66) and hope to be favored with Cheques for said amounts upon return mail, or at your earliest convenience, thanking you very much and favorable reply.

Sincerely,

Nellie Burns,
Indian Teacher

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, informing the Department that Miss Florence A. Gillis has resigned as teacher of the Malagawatch Indian Day School, and nominating the services of Miss Mary Kennedy, who holds a B Scholarship Certificate, for the position to succeed her.

In reply I beg to say that the resignation of Miss Gillis is accepted, and the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss Mary Kennedy to succeed her, to begin duties September 1st, next. Please inform Miss Kennedy of her appointment and arrange with her to begin duties on the date mentioned. We hope that she will meet with every success in her work at this school.

31/12/30
Ottawa, December 16, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, relative to the request of Miss Mary Kennedy, teacher of the Malagawatch Indian Day School, to be granted two months leave of absence during January and February, next, on account of ill health, and that her brother, Colin Kennedy, act as substitute during her absence.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of Miss Kennedy being granted leave of absence for the two months mentioned and her brother replacing her as teacher during her absence. It is hoped that she will be able to resume duties on the 1st of March, next. The qualifications which Mr. Colin Kennedy possesses have been noted. It is hoped that he will be able to carry on the work satisfactorily during the period he is acting as substitute. Salary will be allowed him at the same rate as was paid his sister, but the Department will be unable to allow Miss Kennedy salary for the period she is absent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

C. J. McNeil, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Antigonish, N.S.
Ottawa, April 18th, 1931.

Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of the March quarter return of the Malagawatch Indian Day School. While this return is signed by Mr. Colin Kennedy, it does not state if Miss Mary Kennedy resumed duties at this school on March 1st. (Reference official letter of December 16th, 1930).

In view of Miss Mary Kennedy's services at this school during the past five years, the Department is disposed to allow her, at least, one month's sick leave with pay, but the necessary adjustment in the salaries of herself and her brother cannot be made until we have definite information regarding the length of time that each of them taught during the March quarter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Ottawa, May 6, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, informing the Department that Miss Mary Kennedy, teacher of the Malagawatch Indian Day School, who was allowed two months' leave of absence, did not resume duties upon the expiry of her leave, and has tendered her resignation.

In this connection I have to say that, as recommended by you, Mr. Colin Kennedy, who was appointed substitute teacher, may carry on the work for the balance of the present school year. If you consider that his services would be satisfactory for the next school year, the Department would approve of his appointment, with salary at the rate of $70 per teaching month, the same as he is now receiving as substitute teacher. You may inform him, if you are satisfied regarding his services, that his appointment is approved and also advise the local Indian Agent accordingly.

Your obedient servant,
